title: Recommended
comment: *Edited for patch 1.1Unlike the disappointment that was SimCity 2013, Cities: Skylines is a real city simulator/builder. Every single resident in your city has a home, a job, an education (if you build schools that is), and everyone has somewhere they need to go. You can watch them leave their home, take the subway to the bus stop to take the bus to the mall, and then do the same in reverse to go back home.As someone who fell in love with SimCity when the original came out as shareware in 1989 and have played every Will Wright game since (as well as some of the none-Will Wright followups), I highly recommend Cities: Skylines to anyone who likes city builders. This game is what we wanted from a new SimCity game, without all the bad decisions EA made.The game isn't perfect, but it's pretty damn close. It makes building truly massive cities fun and possible, and with the right hardware the cities look pretty good too with an incredible attention to detail. Building a succesful (profitable) city is fairly easy (easier than SC4 that is), but getting past the 50,000 resident mark, while dealing with traffic, water, power, garbage, and sewage is the real challenge. Getting past the 100,000 resident mark requires some creative thinking in the construction of intersections, highways, and bus lines, but it can be done and you can keep expanding your city until you run out of land to purchase.While the game is a true simulation, it has no natural disasters and if you can keep your city from dying to polluted water or choking in traffic jams, then you can continue building until the budget can't cover it anymore.Traffic has been improved greatly since launch and is now much easier to manage. We've gotten tunnels and the ability to build roundabouts and any other kind of road or rail at any level above and below ground, and the game continues to have some of the best mod support of any game ever released.

title: Recommended
comment: The city builder we've so desperatly craved for a while now. Or at least I know I'm not the only one who did. An addictive game that sucks the hours straight from your soul if you're not careful. It will take a try or two to get the hang of how to build your city, but once you do the mere size of what you can build is immense.It takes some effort to build a city to last, as it will get increasingly busy on the roads once it starts growing. You will probably spend hours on trying to make a traffic-network that isn't too clogged with all those unique people with their own schedule, car and life .. And somehow have a lot of fun doing it.A small downside to me was that, once you've build your immense city up to a certain size, you can get a bit lost on what to do next. There's only so many buildings to unlock and once the city runs, it runs itself. You could probably step away from the computer for an hour, come back and find that the only thing that has changed is how full your garbage dumps, cemetaries and wallet are (Might I add, that I find it hilarious that dead people and garbage have the same mechanic behind it?).The pathfinding for traffic still needs to be tweaked quite a bit too, but overall none of these things take away any of the fun you'll have if you enjoy city builders! Added bonus that, besides adressing the things mentioned above, the developpers have already announced so much shiny stuff they're working on for the future of the game.A hearty two thumbs way up.PS. I'm still convinced that they've added that gorgeous, gorgeous water engine just so that IGN would tell them they've got enough water.

title: Recommended
comment: SimCity was one of the very first games I was ever really hooked on. I vividly remember building cities in black-and-white on my dad's office Macintosh. Since then I've jumped on pretty much any game that claims to be city-builder-ish.And not since SimCity 4, over a decade ago, have I had this much fun building a city from scratch.The scale of the space you can build in is great. Starting with 2km x 2km and eventually expanding out to 9km^2, you can build truly massive cities. What makes that scale even better is you can really divide up your metropolis in a number of ways. From districts that can have individualized govt policies (legal pot, smoke detector ditribution), to localized city services that aren't connected to the larger grid. The game gives you a ton of room to experiment.The one big challenge though you'll face is transportation. Building an effecient city grid of roads, public transit, trains & subways that doesn't have terrible choke points is difficult. Use of elevated bypasses, rail corridors etc are difficult to plan as you don't get access to them until an hour or more into a game, so you may find yourself abandoning your initial city area to build up things "properly" in a newly opened plot of land, then going back and bulldozing your original downtown to start it over again.Beyond the traffic challenge, it can at times be difficult to know why your city isn't growing. Sometimes demand drops to 0 for no apparant reason, then 5 minutes later skyrockets again. There's obviously something going on that's pushing down demand, but as a player it's hard to figure out some times. A few patches to improve UI and reporting will no doubt solve this issue.In the end, the traffic planning and the simulation feedback issues are pretty minor in the face of what's probably the most fun city sim since the glory days of Maxis. And at what I'd consider a "budget" price point, if you're a fan of the genre, this is a must-buy game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Cities Skylines rose when SimCity fell. SimCity was a disaster at launch and was anti consumer with the always online DRM and lying to its customers that it couldn't be turned off. People turned to Cities Skylines and the game sort of became the saviour of the genre.I definitely recommended this game at first but not now. It's gone out of hand with all these DLCs. Even with the sales on, the DLCs cost £55. Significantly more than the game itself. Does this ring a bell? It's just like the EA games. Oh yeah, and without the sales, the DLCs total to around £75. And the game is £22.99.Its become a DLC simulator. You gotta pay for night, pay for a bit of snow, pay for some music update, pay for a special building, Pay for certain transports and disasters and a bunch of different looking buildings.All of those should have been included with the main game for free. Before DLCs were a thing, these were called updates. And updates were free. To top that off, those REALLY are minor upgrades to the game. If you compare to Witcher 3's expansion pass which is another 30-40 extra high quality hours of content on currently on sale for £10. Skylines DLCs really cringe.I don't recommend buying this at full price. Its currently (20-Oct-2017) on sale 75% off, so grab it now if you will. But dont buy anything from them thats not more than 75% off.

title: Recommended
comment: This is the next-generation SimCity that many of us have been waiting for. Strangely enough, it isn't SimCity, and instead is a title made by a team of fewer than 12. It's a great game in many regards. My only complaints would be that traffic is overly complicated to control, and that visual building diversity is lacking.

title: Recommended
comment: The game is very immersive. My first taste of the game sucked me in for a few hours and unlike some games it will entice me back for more as there is plenty to discover. If you're a fan of city builders then you're in for a treat here. Don't expect perfection though as there are a few bugs to iron out (i.e. burger joint signs on drug stores, Fire Engines disappearing off of the map when they should go directly to the burning building) but be assured these are extremely minor bugs that don't take anything away from the fun of the game. With Steam Workshop activated I'm sure they'll be loads to add to the game in future.The main thing i love is the fact that you can play it anyway that you want to - small scale towns/districts, large scale towns/districts - it even has a sandbox mode (unlimited money) if that's your kind of thing.I haven't even got to the public transport side of things but considering Paradox made Cities in Motion as well I'm expecting good things.One last thing to add, I will not be as petty to compare it to similar games in the genre, however it is great that you don't have to be online all the time to play it and the maps can become huge!!Well done the developers. 8.5/10

title: Recommended
comment: Initial ImpressionsWell, I can honestly say that I was looking forward to it. Many comparisons made to Simcity, stemming from a place of fondness of course. While the "Sim" brand will always have a place on my gaming rig (I miss you so much Sim Tower![en.wikipedia.org]), Cities: Skylines delivers on many levels.Current ConsiderationsOkay, lets be succinct: I'm wringing every last bit of playability of the vanilla version for this game before I move on. It's just that good!Cities: Skylines has an asset editor to create your own mods in-game or you can import your own models. The modding community just blossomed within hours of the game release. Without a doubt, I will be using these creative mods in the future and quite possibly creating a few myself.

title: Recommended
comment: Traffic Simulator: God-Can't-Save-You-Now EditionYou can also build a city, but you won't have time for that due to all the traffic that needs fixing.Start the game with 100% city building.After 10,000 residents, welcome to traffic time. From this point forward it's 70% traffic management, 30% city building.After 50,000 residents, it is 100% traffic management. You can't fix it without a degree in traffic control systems.It is fun to watch the subways vomit people on to the streets with each passing train, though.

title: Recommended
comment: It has some flaws (like trains not working for s*** without a lot of gimmicks) but it's still the best city builder, period.The biggest con though, for me, is that it doesn't have an "organig" city growth and administration mechanic. Everything is more about "city designing" if you wish. You end up with cities that are always perfectly planned (the imperfections are only the ones you yourself put in). After you know how the mechanics work there will be little or even nothing to "suprise" you during game play. The game ends up being more about aestethics than it is about city management.I'd like so much for the cities to have a more realistic growth feeling.On the other hand, the pros are just way too long to list. It's good, it's beautiful, it's fun to design a city even if managing it is a bit lackluster. And the devs are pretty cool. The workshop and the modding community are phenomenal. Defo a worth buy.The DLCs, though... Not so much. They're ok, but mostly insanely overpriced for what you get.

title: Recommended
comment: 8/10, would recommend to buy at full price.Cities: Skylines is a game that, for me, is an extension of my younger gaming expiriences. The best way to describe it, without giving the basics (its a city builder/sim), is that I believe this game is the logical continuation of the ENTIRE genre of city builders. What I mean by this is that Cities: Skylines fills the hole left behind after the release of the last major city builder.... Sim City 4.If you grew up on city building, and love the idea of a slightly more technical approach, this game will satisfy. That said, gamers new to the genre, or gamers looking for a city builder with little learning curve, Cities: Skylines can also be a good fit.All in all, a very well made city builder, which runs smooth and with good graphics and technical gameplay, and is also not too hard to learn.

title: Recommended
comment: I've not come to Cities Skylines via Sim City like many reviewers here.I've always found the idea of City Simulators to be a bit dull, but after reading reviews on Steam and spotting a 50% discount, I took a leap of faith and boy was I impressed !!Building roads, housing, water, electricity, school, police, fire, trash, transportation etc. in such a beautiful sandbox is about as much fun as I 've had on a PC in years. Making your population happy and making money for expansion is a surprisingly satisfying activity.Zoning, districts and council policies are all concepts which are introduced gradually without fuss or complication. The 3D game engine is spectacular, intuitive and gorgeous to look at.I had a two thousand citizen city after just a few hours and spent another couple with the game on 'pause' just admiring my creation.I'm months away from modding the game but already I can see huge replayability and value for money.Congratulations to development team - Cities Skylines is clearly a labour of love.I would recommend this game to everyone, especially town planners. (Sorry guys, I confess I used to think you lot were all wierdos!)Buy it.

title: Recommended
comment: I'm currently 12 hours into this game, and I won't look back.Cities: Skylines is one of the best CIty Simulators out now. They literally took what SimCity wanted to do, grew a pair, and did it.Pros:-Great Optimization(My GPU isn't even the "minimal" and I run this on Maximum. w/ a slower CPU.)-Large building space(Yeah, i'm looking at you, EA.)-Mod support from Day 1. Already tons of mods on the Workshop.-Flow of traffic and people is very smooth and feels very responsive.Cons:-No tutorials, figure it out or find a guide.-City seems to stop growing for a while after you hit a ceartain pop. Then correct itself.-Few bugs, but the ones that are there are super annoying.(No crime rates, etc.)Overall I would give this an 8/10 and would say buy it if you are looking for a great City Simulator. Doesn't seem to be much out there doing a better job.

comment: Very entertaining and the best game of its kind i have played to this point.+ it's a HARD game. Easy to learn the basics, but once your city grows bigger you will be facing a lot of new problems (oh god the traffic)+ many different buildings, streets and forms of traffic+ mod support which will increase the actual amount of buildings drastically+ you can spend houndreds of hours on a single city (if you don't fail)+ even then, great replay value+ many little details that make the game even better (clicking on single civilians and see where they are going, what they are thinking, ...)- few annoying bugs that can be changed by deleting a building or restarting the game- monotonous soundtrack that gets extremely annoying after a few hours.

comment: Worth every penny and every GB of RAM on your computer, although I don't like how this game after getting Natural Disasters crashes and gives me the blue screen of death occasionally to this day (yes I reinstalled it, disabled all mods and assets, and make sure my drivers were up to date, I even reset my whole computer) yet it's still crashing, which is why I don't 100% agree with the engine they used to make this game. Although it looks beautiful and extremely realistic, it comes at the cost of lag and lots of crashes (especially if you have a mod and asset addiction like me) unless if you have an extremely good graphics card (I have a Nvidia 750 GTX TI and average 50-80 without mods and max graphics and 24 GB of RAM and with 1257 mods and assets it consumes 21 GB, but has a common chance of not being able to load at all and just crash). All in all, if you have a decent computer and a lot of time to spend, you really should get this game..

title: Recommended
comment: Paradox and Colossal Order give us the best city builder since Sim City 2000. While some may not like Paradox's DLC model (and let's be honest, it can be a bit intimidating for new players), CSL offers loads of awesome content out of the box for a very affordable price. Micro-managers will love the ability to fine tune almost every aspect of their cities, from the names of city districts all the way down to following a single citizen around throughout his day. While there is a bit of a learning curve and the in-game tutorial is rather lacking (a hallmark of Paradox games) there are many youtubers and an official wiki that can help get you up to speed. A great, affordable buy for pretty much anyone!

The transport systems are good, you create bus/train routes and set heavy traffic bans in certain districts. The game looks good and runs smooth as balls and with the support of Steam Workshop I can see this game lasting a long time. If you want a good city builder this is worth full price.

comment: This is what SimCity should have been. Instead of shoehorning in city specializations to make up for the tiny cities, this lets you build GIGANTIC, sprawling cities (especially with mods), where traffic and transit flow is hugely important. Even with the unlimited money cheat, this game is surprisingly difficult to master, but it always feels like your actions have an effect. The only downside so far is that you can't really see what parts of the city rich people live in vs. which parts are poor people. Still, anyone who likes city sims is going to love this one.

title: Recommended
comment: Addictive game. Reminds me of the promises from the first concept art we saw from Sim City (2013) that Maxis' team was unable (or unwilling) to bring to fruition. Collosal Order, you guys are rock stars! I'm beholden to your talent, and I hope we will get some future expansions to this game from you. I also can't wait to see what the modding community will surprise us with.Also, I love the art style of this game. It looks like a photorealistic miniature toy train set, especially with the tilt-shift effect. The freedom I have to place roads, bridges, and pathways is amazing, and they always join naturally and fluidly. Also, you can place objects very close together, so the result is tidy and compact, and very natural looking.

title: Recommended
comment: This is by far my favorite game, and the way I like to spend a decent amount of my free time. This is one of those games that can be played for many hours on end without any chance of boredom. The base game is fantastic and finished, allowing you to create any city you want. The DLC is the way DLC is supposed to be: it adds to the already complete game. Plus, with every major DLC release, the base game gets big updates as well. Importantly, the modding comunity is massive, letting you add in any building you want, change out cars, tweak settings, manage transit, improve Cim AI, and so much more. I cannot reccommend this game enough!

title: Recommended
comment: What an amazing game! Cities Skylines is epic, it has loads and loads and loads of different things in. From Police departments to oil power plants: it is amazing. There is a massive range of things you can do! You can mod it directly from the Steam workshop.Overall Summary:Cities: Skylines is extremely detailed. You have to set up electricity and water plants to make sure everyone gets what they need, and that is not even the start. I am not a fan of city builders, but I am a fan of this one. I think they could add a slight extension to the mods, as you can only have 3.Overall score: 95%

title: Recommended
comment: The game is very immersive. My first taste of the game sucked me in for a few hours and unlike some games it will entice me back for more as there is plenty to discover. If you're a fan of city builders then you're in for a treat here. Don't expect perfection though as there are a few bugs to iron out (i.e. burger joint signs on drug stores, Fire Engines disappearing off of the map when they should go directly to the burning building) but be assured these are extremely minor bugs that don't take anything away from the fun of the game. With Steam Workshop activated I'm sure they'll be loads to add to the game in future.The main thing i love is the fact that you can play it anyway that you want to - small scale towns/districts, large scale towns/districts - it even has a sandbox mode (unlimited money) if that's your kind of thing.I haven't even got to the public transport side of things but considering Paradox made Cities in Motion as well I'm expecting good things.One last thing to add, I will not be as petty to compare it to similar games in the genre, however it is great that you don't have to be online all the time to play it and the maps can become huge!!Well done the developers. 8.5/10

title: Recommended
comment: Though my computer isn't the best for this game, it is good enough that I can form an opinion for it. This game is definitely a step up from the SimCity series. I found that the game was more complex that SimCity 2013 and the traffic A.I. is better. I love how the game manages to densely pack the buildings close together, something SimCity 2013 wasn't able to do. I also like the bigger city size, though with all 25 tiles, it might as well be a reigion. The water physics is also a nice touch, as was the map editor.Something I don't like about the game would be the lack of disasters. In SimCity 2013, the disasters added a challenge to the game. In Cities Skylines, the most difficult challenge would be solving any traffic problems your city has. Really, the worst that can happen is a death wave due to disease or the flooding of a low lying areas. Another thing I don't like is the fact that we can't change what the suspension bridge looks like. Also, the game doesn't really have a good amount of different buildings, meaning that there is often the same building side-by-side. Also, I found that the game suffers from some game glitches due to mods (i.e. Road tools disappearing in the map editor).Overall, I would definitely recommend this game!

title: Recommended
comment: Once upon a time I was going to buy Simcity 2013 when it came out. It was full price but I heard there might be only online problems so I waited until after it was out and tada, there was problems. So I waited.I waited a while. Still had problems.I waited more, they came out with expensive DLC and finally fixed the always online but heard it still had issues with roads and the cities were so small. So I waited for them to fix that. They never did.Price went down. Still had issues, so I waited.They created a game of the year with all the DLC included, fixed a lot of issues and put it on sale for $20. Was thinking on buying it but then they fired everyone that made the game so I knew they would never fix anything else. So I waited.2 days later Cities: Skyline came out. It was worth the wait.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Cities Skylines rose when SimCity fell. SimCity was a disaster at launch and was anti consumer with the always online DRM and lying to its customers that it couldn't be turned off. People turned to Cities Skylines and the game sort of became the saviour of the genre.I definitely recommended this game at first but not now. It's gone out of hand with all these DLCs. Even with the sales on, the DLCs cost £55. Significantly more than the game itself. Does this ring a bell? It's just like the EA games. Oh yeah, and without the sales, the DLCs total to around £75. And the game is £22.99.Its become a DLC simulator. You gotta pay for night, pay for a bit of snow, pay for some music update, pay for a special building, Pay for certain transports and disasters and a bunch of different looking buildings.All of those should have been included with the main game for free. Before DLCs were a thing, these were called updates. And updates were free. To top that off, those REALLY are minor upgrades to the game. If you compare to Witcher 3's expansion pass which is another 30-40 extra high quality hours of content on currently on sale for £10. Skylines DLCs really cringe.I don't recommend buying this at full price. Its currently (20-Oct-2017) on sale 75% off, so grab it now if you will. But dont buy anything from them thats not more than 75% off.

title: Recommended

comment: "The city sim that Sim City (2013) should have been" pretty much sums it up.Most of its minor flaws (depending on personal preference) can be ironed out with mods, for which there is a very active community. Also, the developers have been diligently patching the game and I'd like to point out that the European map & buildings pack included for free in the last update would have probably been sold as a DLC by most of their competitors.

title: Recommended
comment: A worthy successor to Sim City 4's mantle, it's everything that Simcity 2013 wasn't; completely moddable, possesses large cities, functioning simulations and much more. Furthermore the artstyle is truly beautiful. Everything is easy and seemless to do. Want to relocate a firestation without rebuilding it? There's a button for that. Want to create a freehand road junction to navigate an awkward area of the city? Very intuitive to do. It is overall a very solid game, with few problems, so I thoroughly recommend it to anyone with a passing interest in city building.9/10.

title: Recommended
comment: Pretty much the only city builder out there:- Game looks nice, unlike SimCity 4- Engine doesn't start ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ itself after you build a district or two (like Cities XL)- You don't fill the map within an hour of playing like SimCity 2014- It's an actual city builder (to not compare it with games like Banished/Anno that are fine in their own genre)And as a bonus it's totally open to mods (can go from extra buildings to new features) with a steam workshop integration and I'm really looking forward to what will be available on that side within a few weeks/months.

title: Recommended
comment: I have to admit, I never really got into the whole city simulation genre. I always wanted to tryr out SimCity, but with all the bad reviews of the newest one, I strayed away and never looked back. After seeing some videos of Cities: Skylines I figured I'd try it. I'll say thing. Cities: Skylines is one of the best games I've played in quite a long time.As a newcomer to the genre, I found it easy enough to get a grasp on the basics fairly quickly. Don't mistake that for being easy though. After going for about 10 hours my city went into a chain reaction because my trash collection wasn't up to par. My citizens got sick, died, and then their homes were left abandoned, leading to lower property values for the rest of the homes. Within 30 minutes I went from a thriving and growing city of 60,000 citizens to a bankrupt city of 5000. It was a real reminder that the city you build is delicate, and can be destroyed past the point of no return with a single mistake.Overall, the game makes it easy to understand yet remains a challenge at the same time. The UI is easy to use and has never given me issues. The game also runs VERY smoothly, even when your city reaches large populations.Cities: Skylines is certainly worth a look whether you're a veteran SimCity player or new to the genre.

title: Recommended
comment: Traffic Simulator: God-Can't-Save-You-Now EditionYou can also build a city, but you won't have time for that due to all the traffic that needs fixing.Start the game with 100% city building.After 10,000 residents, welcome to traffic time. From this point forward it's 70% traffic management, 30% city building.After 50,000 residents, it is 100% traffic management. You can't fix it without a degree in traffic control systems.It is fun to watch the subways vomit people on to the streets with each passing train, though.

title: Recommended
comment: I'm currently 12 hours into this game, and I won't look back.Cities: Skylines is one of the best CIty Simulators out now. They literally took what SimCity wanted to do, grew a pair, and did it.Pros:-Great Optimization(My GPU isn't even the "minimal" and I run this on Maximum. w/ a slower CPU.)-Large building space(Yeah, i'm looking at you, EA.)-Mod support from Day 1. Already tons of mods on the Workshop.-Flow of traffic and people is very smooth and feels very responsive.Cons:-No tutorials, figure it out or find a guide.-City seems to stop growing for a while after you hit a ceartain pop. Then correct itself.-Few bugs, but the ones that are there are super annoying.(No crime rates, etc.)Overall I would give this an 8/10 and would say buy it if you are looking for a great City Simulator. Doesn't seem to be much out there doing a better job.

title: Recommended
comment: An amazing City Building game that takes personalization to another level! There's a lot of content, enough to have you playing for hours and hours. Most people viewing or playing this game have been introduced to SimCity so I'll break it down. There is more content in this game than in SimCity and it's also HALF the price that was at launch. The Map Sizes, with the current mod, can be up to 25 times the map size in SimCity, most computers cannot handle that though so it's a do at your own risk which is fine. The graphics are great and it runs flawlessly on my i7 4790k. The content for this game has unlimited potential in the future. Basically if you like City Builders and Simulators than this is the game for you, it's what SimCity and Cities XXL should have been, hands down (: Also there really isn't any bugs, at least none that I've experienced so far.

title: Recommended
comment: this game is beautifull, well presented and great to play, I would recommend it hands down as it is not the most expensive game and has great support for modding and workshop content.however the road system needs quite a bit of work as cars seem to only use 1 of 2 left turn lanes on 6 lane roads which piles them together in very long traffic jams causing trucks to not be on time with deliveries, the emergency services also get stuck in this traffic instead of driving past is as they would in real life.the end game does make the game less enjoyable but workshop content will hopefully fix that.all in all a great game and has everything that simity has not got.

title: Recommended
comment: I've really looked forward to this game. Feel like I can give an early impressions review.Pros:- Performance is very good, smooth, the camera never stutters. Have felt no slow-ups.- Easy to pick up the nuances of the game.- Pretty.- Mods. And this will save the game (see cons)Cons:- I feel like there isn't much variety in types of buildings. The mods however should over time offer a massive amount of content and I feel like it's only a matter of that this comment becomes irrelevant.- Small gripe, but why can't the different lines be different colours? I find it really confusing and quite finicky to create a bus line.- Another small gripe, but the two different blues used for Offices and Light Commercial are too similar, I often click the wrong one.- Not very...exciting? It's fun to play, its light hearted, its nice to kill a bit of time but after an hour or two I found myself logging out. Some sort of immersion is missing. There isn't that much do apart from expand your city, there's no trade (not that I have yet seen) for example. Maybe having some "ghost AI" cities far on the horizon that you can't visit but see could be connecting to your city and then opening possibilities of trade would be really awesome and give more emphasis on feeling that you're part of a connected world. At the moment it just feels very isolated.-----------------------------------------------Overall, it's worth the money and fun to play even it's a bit shallower than I had hoped.

By the way, it is a 5 star game, fair price, very open to modding and very close to simcity in its best years, but much more improved. If you are a SimCity player already, the game experience should feel familiar, so not very difficult to start. Buy it.

Wonky road connections are not.The amount of liesure activities are poor and filling space basically amounts to plopping trees. Some land fillers etc much like a Cities XL mods would be welcome.A much better highway/road system is required. Creating life-like ideas with roads turns out to be terrible, aesthetically.Negatives:- Road Snap.- Single lane sliproads.- Cars not using inside lane on roundabouts.- Inability to set road/lane priority etc.- Leisure activites limited.- Lack of upgrades for services etc.- Tunnels.- No Terraforming except entire map creation, nothing while playing.- Multiplayer?- Overlays are limited.- Lack of real information.Positives:- Turn it on, build a city.- Easy difficulty.- Trains/Metro/Buses.- Modding tools.- Steam Works. Thousands of prefab intersections within first day and mods.- Cost.- District creation.- Simple at it's core.Would restructure districts again.

title: Recommended
comment: A real return to city building greatness.I approached Cites:Skylines with a small amount of trepidation, I have already been burnt by the disappointment that was the most recent Sim City.However Cities:Skylines is no Sim City clone. Rather it takes a lot of the best elements of the Sim City franchise, and puts them into a very a slick, playable and user friendly package. The game is friendly to a new user, introducing new elements and features over time in a gated sense, but don't be mistaken it isn't impossible to fail, on my very first city I managed to bankrupt myself before I had proper infrastructure or even a few buildings because of my complex and excessively ambitious waste management and water system. From the get go there is a lot to do providing an engaging experience, but not so much as to overwhelm. There is enough detail and content to introduce the newer player gradually whilst simultaneously allowing players with more experience new ways to improve and experiment.You start off small, with a few roads and your very most basic amenities and infrastructure for water and electricity. You attract a few hundred people, build a school, and start expanding your commercial center. Before you know it you are the mayor of a town of 50,000, rebuilding motorways, managing 6 lane roundabouts and trying to build a spaghetti roller-coaster of a highway junction to alleviate excessive congestion as traffic pours into your Metropolis to visit your colossal skyscrapers. It is a very satisfying experience, through your own strategy and planning you have turned a small dull field with a few small houses into a buzzing, noisy city with a real character of your own choosing.Despite how enjoyable the game has been so far in the short term, my most considerable worry going into the future is the potential lack of replay value. You build your infrastructure , you grow your city, you put amenities and services. The play pattern every game is pretty much identical, and there are very few randomly generated elements to change this. Combined with the lack of multiplayer capability really begs the question what will keep players coming back for more. However this is certainly somewhat alleviated by the games innate modability and interaction with the steam workshop, which seems to add a lot of capability and even quality of life fixes to the game.This game has such a low price-tag that you could easily get your value for money in a few play throughs, and even if you do get burnt out there is not much to lose. The game also has all of the appropriate attributes to evolve and grow with the release of DLC and steam workshop content, making it a really appealing prospect to come back to when you feel like a spending your time building a city.The game is fairly slow tempo by design, this shouldn't be a surprise it's being a city builder not Call of Duty. If slower simulation games (Civilization, city management games, Rome Total War etc) are not to you preference then I can't really suggest this will do much to change that. It's a great game for relaxing, and thinking, but its not high tempo competitive nor challenging game. Though that does not mean it isn't engaging, there is always something to do and things ever changing as you grow your city, it always keeps the player considering of ways to improve/diversify or grow the city.The lack of multiplayer is a missed opportunity. Had the game had similar multiplayer functionality to the most recent Sim City, such as if there was some way of building concurrent cities that would evolve and change depending on a friend''s decisions in real time would have made for an even more complete experience. At the very least better functionality in terms of sharing cities and visiting cities created by friends would add a lot discussion and interaction, but I imagine these features are possibilities for the future, the game itself is a great platform which could be easily extended to a mutliplayer experience which I feel would round off the experience and add significant longevity.4/5.A very good city building simulation that is very accessible, with a user friendly and functional UI and variable gameplay pacing. The game is simultaneously relaxing yet intriguing, and ultimately leaves the player feel very satisfied.The steam workshop, and other modability means the game may continue to grow, but the static gameplay pattern with very little variability or random events and no current multiplayer make the longevity questionable.

comment: Best City builder in YEARS! You won't be disapointed if you love city builders. I'm only 3 hours in and the quality over Simcity 13 is apparent from the start. I've seen some people complain about the graphics but they are good. Hightly recommended!!

comment: It's early March and I'm prepared to call this Game of the Year right now. It's the SimCity you've always wanted. It's perfection. It's beautiful. It's dense. It's entertaining. It's affordable. I don't think this game will ever be uninstalled from my computer.

comment: So I've played this for 5 1/2 hours straight and can confirm its one of the best City builders out there. It is exactly what Simcity 2013 should have been if EA didnt ♥♥♥♥ up so much. Even though its only launch day I would already rate this as one of the best city builders out there.

title: Recommended
comment: They have actually done it. EDIT: BUT... read the end of the review.To be frank, I was skeptical if this wasn't just overhyped in the wake of the SC13 and CXL debacles, but from what I could gather in the 5 hours it has glued me to the screen tonight, Cities Skylines might be the SC4 successor we have been waiting for. The game is easy in the beginning, but not overly so and traffic and garbage can be a challenge even with 8k residents (although not an unfair one). The simulation is responsive and detailed. The interface is confusing at first but you get used to it quickly enough. They reduced SC4's diagram bloat but sadly some useful ones fell victim as well.Soundtrack is nice but rather repetitive, and the modding community will need to figure out if we can make this as pretty and diverse as SC4 was eventually.I didn't like Skylines' art style from the previews, but playing the game it grows on you. The visual fidelity in the lowest zoom levels is lacking, but you have the reassurance that what you are seeing is actually simulated, unlike SC13. You can see individual citizens, but I sort of miss the traffic flow maps from buildings in SC4RH.Variety is enough to keep me going for a couple dozen hours. I'll update this review once Skylines has passed the test of time ;)EDIT: So, I have played for 25 hours now, and thats it for now. Sorry, but the lack of gameplay depth and seeing the same building 10 times next to the others really won't keep me coming back. Yes there is the workshop, but its an unsorted mess and sifting through the thousands of reskinned buildings to find the occasional new one is exhausting. We need some content curators or new gameplay content fast.

title: Recommended
comment: To me, it reminds me to the older version of SimCity. They take bits and pieces from SimCity 3000, SimCity 4 and SimCity 2013 to make this game. Sure there are a few minor bugs, but nowhere near enough to ruin the experience. If you are an old-school SimCIty player, you will like this game.

title: Recommended
comment: This is a rare gem of a game- the kind that you keep on playing in your head even when you left the computer.City-building at it's finest. Easy to use interface, logical connections and the joy when you see your first skyscrapers building up... or when you complete especially challenging highway intersection and it works. Priceless.

title: Recommended
comment: Best city building game ever... and I don't just say that lightly. It has the depth and complexity of the best of the Sim City games mixed with sleek modern graphics.Your City live breathes and evolves constantly through the game, as you grapple to keep it from falling into enviromental and economic disaster.The only disadvantage to this game is the lack of unique disaster events, e.g earthquakes, that the Sim City franchise featured. However the developer has promised to patch them into the game.With strong features, engaging and complex game play as well as Steam Workshop mod support, Cities Skylines in everything that the recent Sim City reboot should have been.

title: Recommended
comment: Easily the best city builder to come around in a long time. It also does alot to bring new wrinkles into the established formula. Being able to name and customize pretty much anything in the game is fantastic. And also having the ability to create separate districts within the city is a great addition. You can even set different policies within each district. Want an area with no smoking? You can do that. Want people to recycle? Click the checkbox.Only thing I'd say that could be considered 'negative' would be that you can't take any loans out until you reach a population of 400+. So if you get a little overzealous when starting out (like I did), you might find yourself in a bind. You can take a Bailout, but then that disables being able to do certain things.Overall I'm really enjoying the game, and I can see this being a top played for me for awhile.

It's a great game for relaxing, and thinking, but its not high tempo competitive nor challenging game. Though that does not mean it isn't engaging, there is always something to do and things ever changing as you grow your city, it always keeps the player considering of ways to improve/diversify or grow the city.The lack of multiplayer is a missed opportunity. Had the game had similar multiplayer functionality to the most recent Sim City, such as if there was some way of building concurrent cities that would evolve and change depending on a friend''s decisions in real time would have made for an even more complete experience. At the very least better functionality in terms of sharing cities and visiting cities created by friends would add a lot discussion and interaction, but I imagine these features are possibilities for the future, the game itself is a great platform which could be easily extended to a mutliplayer experience which I feel would round off the experience and add significant longevity.4/5.A very good city building simulation that is very accessible, with a user friendly and functional UI and variable gameplay pacing. The game is simultaneously relaxing yet intriguing, and ultimately leaves the player feel very satisfied.The steam workshop, and other modability means the game may continue to grow, but the static gameplay pattern with very little variability or random events and no current multiplayer make the longevity questionable.

title: Recommended
comment: (Note: This is essentially my review script I used for my video review, so some of this review may sound strange without the video accompaniment)YouTube™ Video: KTG Reviews: Cities: Skylines | Is It Worth It? Views: 251Just something different I thought I'd try. So join me as I endeavor to answer, is it worth it? If you enjoy my videos please hit that like button and consider subscribing!Fans of city simulation games have bore an itch that has not been scratched. I’ve felt that itch as well, waiting for a quality successor to one of my favorite simulation games, and possibly one of my favorite games I had growing up. That game is SimCity 4. Since SimCity 4 came out in 2003, there has been no game that I felt was worthy of being called it’s successor. Games like Cities: XL and even Maxis’s own SimCity (which came out in 2013) have failed to produce an experience like the ever popular SimCity 4.Cities: Skylines (Which has no relation to the CitiesXL Franchise) is from the makers of the Cities in Motion franchise, a series focused primarily on managing a cities traffic. And funnily enough traffic is one of the few things I believe this game struggles with, but we’ll discuss that later.So first, lets just have a quick overview of the game.After a brief loading screen which provides you with a few random tips and tricks, you’ll be presented with your map. And a message, on the bottom right that serves as a basic and unintrusive tutorial.I generally don’t care for pop-up text tutorials, but I think colossal order did a good job, the tutorial is simple to skip and disable, as well as read and understand, and it doesn’t impact your game in a negative way.In order to build anything you will need a connection with the outside world. You do this by simply selecting the road, being presented with another easy to understand tutorial, and clicking and dragging the road to its desired length.Simple enough right? It’s been done this way in nearly every city sim I’ve ever played, it works, so it doesn’t need fixing. I think that is the same approach colossal order took while developing this game. They took everything that works in a city builder, and put it in the game. For the most part they succeeded. And where they may have failed, both in opinion and reality, users are empowered via to the Steam Workshop to create the game experience they want.This is all they had to do! This is all maxis and ea had to do to create an experience that will last a long time. Simply take what people liked from SimCity 4 and move it into the next generation of modern computing. Thats it.Now, this isn’t to say Cities: Skylines doesn’t have its faults, because it certainly does.There are some minor ones, graphically the game isn’t stunning. There are no filters and it’s just kind of grey. Although the included color correction tool in the options menu may change the visual styling more to your liking, it is very limiting only providing you with 4 options. Perhaps this can be rectified with mods, in fact it may have already been, considering there are over 30,000 mods as of this review.Another gripe I had was the lack of variety in buildings. From a distance this isn’t so noticeable, but zoom in to any one neighborhood, and you will be presented with a plethora of identical looking homes. Both in appearance and color palate.Additionally, the lack of any disaster mechanic such as what you’d find in the SimCity series is disappointing. It could have been a great way to make cities more memorable. Which brings me to another point.Often times I’d find myself playing this game for several hours in one sitting, building a city up from nothing, to a thriving megalopolis. Only to abandon the city the next day I play simply because my cities don’t feel special to me. Perhaps its just a failing of my personal style of play, or perhaps its a strike against Cities: Skylines.One of the primary issues you encounter is traffic. Traffic management quickly becomes your primary concern once your city begins to grow. It is unclear to me if this was by design or simply an undesired consequence of how the game handles “agents.”What I mean by agents is that every single moving speck, also known as your citizens, has a purpose or function, they aren’t simply randomly moving around the city with no purpose. Every delivery truck has a destination and source, just as every citizen has a job and a home. What this means, is that without careful traffic management and planning, you can experience bottlenecks, due to either your own incompetence or perhaps just how the game handles traffic, which seems to direct traffic based on the shortest distance available, and doesn’t take into account congestion.There are some other smaller gripes I have, but traffic is by far the biggest antagonist I have seen. Which brings me to another point. Beyond traffic, there is really not any end goal or ongoing metric that you have to manage. Which can turn some people off if they are looking for the game to tell them what to do, which it really doesn’t. There are some achievements or milestones, based on population which unlock new services. But these stop after 80,000 population. Meaning if you’re playing just to unlock everything, congratulations, you’ve just done it.In addition to milestones as an ongoing goal, you can also unlock unique buildings, which are earned by meeting certain requirements. For example, once your city has the airport, you can unlock the Grand Mall, which improves metrics like tourism, attractiveness and entertainment.But again, this is really all there is if you’re looking for a sense of progression. You have to create your own milestones if you really want to enjoy this game to its fullest extent. But even then, you are not experiencing all this game has to offer.The best way to play this game is with mods. There are a myriad of mods, which promise to fix nearly every problem I have encountered.A mod fixed the obnoxious color of pollution in the water and ground. A mod let me correct the direction of my roads without the need to delete and replace them. They have added in game terraforming, they allow me to place roads on top of roads.In short the possibilities of this game, as well as it’s long term viability are essentially endless. Thanks to the modding support provided by the devs, and the catalyst that is the steam workshop, making the installation of these mod files painless.This is the game that may very well dethrone what is often considered the definitive city builder, SimCity 4.Now, there's simply the matter of answering the original question I posed at the beginning of this video: Is it worth it?Despite it’s minor failings with traffic management and building variety, I think I can confidently say that this game is indeed worth the bargain price of $29.99.

The Map Sizes, with the current mod, can be up to 25 times the map size in SimCity, most computers cannot handle that though so it's a do at your own risk which is fine. The graphics are great and it runs flawlessly on my i7 4790k. The content for this game has unlimited potential in the future. Basically if you like City Builders and Simulators than this is the game for you, it's what SimCity and Cities XXL should have been, hands down (: Also there really isn't any bugs, at least none that I've experienced so far.

title: Recommended
comment: My mayoral skills were impressive. In a short time I'd grown my little hamlet from just a few hundred residents into a gleaming city of 70,000 people. But suddenly, it all fell apart. My garbage collection services ran into a problem: the roads leading to my district of landfills and incinerators couldn't handle the vast amount of garbage trucks coming and going from all corners of the city. An enormous traffic jam started - unnoticed at first - eventually cascading into every corner of the city, completely locking down the road system. Fires raged through the down town high-rises because the fire fighters couldn't make it past the traffic. Sick people started dying in their homes because ambulances couldn't get to their door. As the bodies piled up and the buildings burned down, complaints rolled in and people started abandoning the city as quickly as they could.Where Skylines truly shines is in its focus on transportation management. As my story at the beginning showed, poorly planned roads can destroy your city once it outgrows the infrastructure. Fortunately, you have scads of options to manage your transportation. You can build underground or elevated roads, low or high volume streets (including one-way streets!), bus stations, subways, trains, and more. Mass transit becomes incredibly important as you quickly realize you want to get as many cars off the streets as possible, and you'll find yourself building pedestrian pathways to make it easy for your citizens to walk everywhere. You can easily spend the majority of your time fiddling to find the most optimal traffic solution if you want to - and sometimes you'll need to, as the game will harshly punish you if your traffic infrastructure can't handle your people.The game also introduces the concept of "districts". In the Sim City games you were able to enact laws and policies that effected the city as a whole, but in Skylines you can create individual districts and then enact policies on a district level if you don't want them to impact the entire city. This allows you to build a booming business sector with tax breaks for commercial zoning and free public transport while banning truck traffic and high rises in a quiet residential neighborhood.I unabashedly adore Cities: Skylines. Despite that, there are still some issues I have with the game - issues which, granted, have been addressed by mods, but still need to be added as official features.Pedestrian pathways were very exciting to me as a long-time Sim City player. The transportation options haven't ever allowed you to build a "walkable" city. In Skylines, while you can build them to allow your people to walk everywhere, you can't place buildings or zones off pedestrian pathways, which means that citizens have to use the path to walk to a road to go to a building. They essentially just allow you to place shortcuts connecting roads and don't let you create any sort of walkable city area.You also don't have any fine-tuned control over your intersections. Given how essential a proper road layout is, you'd expect to be able to designate turn lanes, cross-walk locations, and whether your want an intersection to have traffic signals or not. As it is, intersections are automatically created and you have no control over what exactly they look like. This can be very frustrating if you're trying to optimize your traffic flow.Planting trees is also a pain, as you can only place individual trees - there's no way to place mass amounts with a brush, and it's sorely needed.None of those problems have lessened by enjoyment with the game, and indeed, most of them arose only after spending many hours playing..

comment: Probably the best city simulator at the moment. The game is complex, innovative and downright addictive. Graphics are pretty and well made. This game could have been really great if it weren't for the dlc's Paradox keeps on releasing. Adding one distinct building doesn't make my gaming experience better in any ways. If they were to release a dlc which only contains one building they should make it free in my opinion. Buy this game when it's on sale and if you're into simulation games otherwise pass and look for another city simulator.

title: Recommended
comment: I have enjoyed playing management/city building/strategy games since they first start appearing in the early 1980's and recently I was asked to start reviewing mods for Cities: Skylines on a couple of websites.Why Cities:Skylines, well it has an amazing modding community that has transformed an above average city building game into an amazing one. The majority of these coders are quiet and unassuming and simply brillant, while a few others are worse than Kanye West (arrogant, self righteous with their heads stuck up their own a backsides) and only so-so coders that blame their short-comings on others. But all-in-all it has a great community that is always coming up with new ideas for making this game more realistic and fun.City building doesn't get much better than this. The modding community has already made this game so much better and CO are still adding new features.If you are a die-hard city-builder or a novice, this game is a must. Great game as it is now, The definitive city-builder game in the future.

title: Recommended
comment: Two years out and and maybe still the best modern city building-strategy game you can get. Just relaxing, if you manage to keep the traffic moving. The Cities feel so alive and you might wanna follow someone, and see your citizens driving to work, visiting soccer games, taking the dog for a walk and many other activities.There are many dlcs for Cities: Skylines, but judge for yourself. I only bought the After Dark dlc yet and it sure looks great, but for a dlc which mostly just gives you a day and night cycle, with nice lighting, it's a proud price to pay. A day and night cycle could just be part of the game from start.But also without any dlc the game is great and has a nice modding community, where you get a lot of things to add. Or you might teach yourself to work with the editor and create your own buildings, parks and roads.

title: Recommended
comment: Recommended purchase.The idea behind other city simulations finally done better in every aspect. Additionally deep, but not overwhelming, and complex, but not complicated, with a well designed and easy to use and accessible UI. Simply endless fun.If you are looking for city simulators, you can look at all the others - you found the best one here with Cities: Skylines, no doubt and by far.Now, a year after release, there is even a whole scene of YouTubers, who use the unlimited money mod of this game and spend all their time mainly with the design features of the in-game city editor and who then use the city simulation component of the game only to bring life to the backdrop of their creations - much like building a model railroad, only in your computer and way cooler.If you want to just casually play a few hours and create a small town, or if you intend to go deeper into the concepts, that depends practically only on you, on what you want to do with the game. Both seems to be possible with the game, for one part probably because of the game's accessibility.I've bought it shortly after release, about a year ago, and unfortunately didn't play with it since (only 20hrs seeing if it works), until recently.Now, after a three week vacation, one year and two DLC packs later, I can see bazillions of workshop items to enhance the game, tutorials of varying depth and orientation on video platforms and in written form on Steam/reddit/imgur, that can help mastering the challenges of the game with less experimenting and more method and intent from your side. A lot of people have shared their experiences online, go look..During these past three weeks I've spent about 40 more hours with Cities: Skylines, additionally about 10 hours of reading up on actual urban planning science and watching a number of videos from more experienced gamers. Yes, Cities: Skylines is a game, and because of that it is of course a simplified version of reality. The game's challenges are still very much oriented in the real world challenges of urban planning and you can actually verify your own ideas on how to solve any of these situations of growth and tackle the multicausal nature of your city situation.Also, probably because the game's background simulation is much more complex under the hood than it may seem on the surface, every city you may create is an individual bunch of problems and you'll never find any magic bullet solution for any of your problems anywhere. It's amazing to see how playing the game more systematically can enhance your world view.There's usually far more than one way to do things in the game, the creators seem to have encouraged this by their game design and also seem to have encouraged the community to be creative and enhance the game with mods. Under the hood of the game everything looks fairly modern, my fast i7 4GHz gaming rig is actually doing some work here and I haven't even reached the 2^16 simulation agent limit, yet.Anyway, because of its fine surface polish, low price, peaceful and educationally valuable content, this game can be recommended to anyone anyway. It's a fine game no questions asked, no matter for who or how you look at it. It think there can be not much substantial doubt in this. That's why I thought I'd owe this game at least a review, as it is a masterpiece in every aspect I can think of. And I think it was not just one head who created this game, it feels like many people put their best together successfully to create this game.It's especially recommended for people, who look for more than just a timesink and it can probably easily be like that. I think, I'm learning a lot for my life, like multitasking, making better decisions, being more disciplined - just by playing this game. A perfect gift.There's just one other game I know of that I could easily spend hundreds of hours with, and already did. Cities: Skylines is another one in this rare kind.I'm really amazed by what Colossal Order created here and I'm thankful for their efforts. It delivers on pretty much everything I've been waiting for since 1989 and more. Thank you!

title: Recommended
comment: This is what Simcity 2013 should have been. It is the only game since simcity 4 in 2003 to achieve this excellent of a complete city managing system, and is equally as supported by some of the best mods on steam. I struggle to think of enough superlatives to describe this game.(warning, it is a very cpu heavy game, not on the gpu. It also eats up ram, a large city would easily use 12gb on its own. If you're sitting on 8gb or less, i would strongly recommend upgrading to 16gb as you will see significant frame increases.)Furthermore, For what feels like the $100 game simcity was going to be, this thing's only $30!! Simcity 2013 was the first and last preorder i ever made, and i feel now that I spent the $30 on simcity, and the $100 on Cities Skylines. Because that is what those two games are worth.You would be a fool not to buy it.

title: Recommended
comment: Essentially everything the sequal to SimCity 4 should have been, this game is. Huge maps, the ability to create districts with different governing policies, and the budget management that was lacking in other games exists here. The transit system creation (down to being able to place the lines, and add express trains to busy subway tracks, etc, and the ability to create unique highway interchanges and road paths make this game come to life more than most city building games ever have.

title: Recommended
comment: ==OVERVIEW==I had never played a city builder before this. But I have a personal grudge with EA so I refuse to buy anything from them so never tried any of the Simcity series.Then I learn of cities skylines and I find that lo and behold its on sale. As I wanted to try a city simulator I bought it to try out. That night instead of going to bed at midnight, I was up to 7 am when I finally went to sleep. It can be that addicting, I would of bought it at full price had I known.So this is a fantastic game, and approaching 300 hours on it I can say its been worth all of it. The game isn't flawless mind you, but its pros far outweigh its cons.==PROS==Ease of use - The game is very easy to pickup. There is an included tips bar for beginners but its pretty easy to intuit what you need to do without it. The interface is clearly labeled if you hover over any button. Not once did I feel i had to consult an online guide until I was trying new an crazy ideas.Sound - Sounds effects are generic and eh, sounds of traffic and the like. But the music is highly atmospheric and while simple its satisfying. Beyond the music there are various "radio stations" you can pick with some humorous radio hosts and decent songs, both original and licensed. Normally when building things I listen to my own music but for this game i tend to just listen to the game's sounds.Editors - Don't like how something looks? Need a specific type of road or park? The game includes many content editors build in. I have been making custom road types to fill in the gaps the developers left. And let's be fair to them, there is no way they could every type of road possible without disastrously cluttering up the UI. But you can also import your own models to add, really, whatever you want to the game. The terrain editor is easy to use for making your own maps. There are still editors I've yet to use but my outlook for them is hopeful.Workshop - Made something with the above editors? The steam workshop interface is fantastic and easy to get whatever you made available for others. And its easy to search to find what you are after, assuming of course someone has made it. From mods to buses it lets you expand your game considerably.Mods - I'm no modder so I can't talk about ease of modding the game but as for ease of using the mods, its one of the easiest I have encountered. Simply subscribe to the mod you want on the workshop and turn it on in the game's conent manager, in the main menu. No manipulating files, not confusing setups, just click and done. And the community mods generally fix most of the in game cons.==CONS==Traffic AI - Let's talk about easily the most frustrating part of this game, Traffic. While making the city is great and all but traffic is the lifeblood to make the city function. And the traffic has horrible AI. It picks the shortest route when it starts, and come hell or high water it will stick to the route if the player hasn't removed or changed the road in route. Which means if there is a problem in route it will just back up. You also can't control how lanes connect at interest ions which makes it very difficult to try to direct traffic. All you can do is place roads and pick if an interaction has a light, which sides have stop signs, or if its unregulated. Real life cars have access to traffic reports so they can talk alternative routes, it would be nice to see that in this game. Or if "residential" cars were more savvy as to the bad roads the "new" or "tourist" cars.Annoying Building Requirements - This is more a personal gripe then a real flaw. There are unique buildings you can make in the game, such as malls, telescopes, etc. But they all have some sort of building requirements. Not just space and cost but to unlock them you have to do some, odd tasks. The good news is these tasks carry across all maps so once you do it once you have the building for good. But making this happen... Some are simply, like have X amount of a type of building. Some require a certain event to happen. but the frustrating ones are when you have to have "X condition for Y amount of time." And example is to get the Lazert Plaza you have to bring your entire city to low average health, which is a tall order in and of itself difficult without killing everyone, but you have to maintain it for several weeks which is hard as the population dies or leaves the number of remaining people is more healthy, so the average health rises.Chirpper - Chirpper is then in game messenger the citizens use and is an obvious parody of twitter. Sometimes this is useful as it lets you know about problems, like part of the city doesn't have running water. But the vast majority is flavor, like liking or not liking a zoning plan or decision you made. Its amusing to read once or twice, but it never stops. And there is no options for Chirpper other then the hat to give its interface.Mod-Limitation - While i love the modding, you are limited with how many mods it lets you run at once. Just let me run mods and its my fault if I put to many to run. This is compounded by several build in mods, like unlimited money and unlock everything are all separate mods and count as 1 each, so if you want them you cut down drastically on the number of community mods you can run.DLC Prices - While the game is good, the DLC prices can seem a bit obnoxious at times.==CONCLUSION==Yeah its got its flaws. But its a very fun experience which I would recommend to any city simulator fan, or someone wanting to try the genre out.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Is this a good sim city builder game... When you first look at it without knowing the facts... Yeah, Kinda.Is this a good way to waste a few hours... YesThe base game seems ok at first, then you start to realise how much is missing when compared to other sim city games of the last 30yrs... Want a few disasters to entertain you and murder some civs... PAY EXTRA... want to experience winter... PAY EXTRA... Want to expoerience night time in your city... PAY EXTRA.. want to have a single extra building.. PAY EXTRA... want another building.. PAY EXTRA.When I say PAY EXTRA... we're not talking about a few pemmies or pounds/dollars here and there... here in the UK, we are talking a MINIMUM of £10 for each of the following Winter/Disasters/After Dark and even more for the newest Green Cities... and if you want some extra buildings... PAY EXTRA AGAIN AND AGAIN AND AGAIN.I think you get the idea... The base game is in fact a stripped down, not as good as the original sim city of 30yrs ago... poor attempt at a sim game. Every decent idea was removed when they realised they could sell it for extra cash to those foolish enough to fall for their scams.There are some decent mods available from the steam workshop... but many of these are incompatible with updates to the game or require certain DLC's to function at all. So you are left with a game that frequently crashes because you don't have something a mod relys on... Not a good way to play so you end up removing virtually all community mods to stop the random crashes.So... IS IT VALUE FOR MONEY.. NO!!!.. In fact.. F*CK NO!!! You'd have to spend hundreds to get the full game.. and then get screwed again and again as they add new stuff down the road. They didn't even do the decent thing and release a season pass that gets you all new DLC as it's released... Because they know they can screw you more by charging you for EVERY LITTLE TINY EXTRA.Unless you can pick this game up including all of the DLC for less than £15-20 (30 USD) then DO NOT buy it.The devs are simply screwing over their customers, constantly releasing overpriced DLC that some muppets will rush out and buy like the sad little fanbois they are.Instead, keep your wallet/purse in your pocket/bag and save it until such a time as everything is greatly reduced.DO NOT reward greedy, deceitful and underhand practices by gaming devs/publishers because it will only encourage them to continue ripping people off.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Don't get me wrong this is a great game. Well designed, looks beautiful, few to no apparent bugs.But to make its users pay an additional $75 for DLC that could and should have been included in the original package, this is shameful.I will not be buying any DLC, for this or any other game. We as the consumers need to stand up to this bull and not pay into this sort of sales strategy.Shame on you, developers.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I love this game. I honestly do.I play it when I am bored, frustrated, or just looking for some casual strategy.I've made a large number of cities, of varying sizes and forms.I've spent hours upon hours improving the lives of AI that don't understand not to drive straight into pools of water on a road, or how to use multiple lanes on a road to avoid traffic.I've downloaded so many mods for this that at points I don't even recognize the game I'm playing anymore.But, I've also spent money on this game.Not just the base game, no, no.$30 or so on material that should be IN the base game.Oh, sure, seeing my city at night is beautiful, and it makes me feel powerful seeing the lights of highrises mix with distant suburban houses and shops. But, that power is gone as soon as I realize that I had to PAY to experience night.$15 to have a BASIC feature in the game.What about snow? Different looks for houses and shops? Disasters? Concerts?No, none of those are in the base game, except the different styles which are in mods.And now: Free content for people who didn't spend money on our new DLC! You get some parks and trees!This is not "better" than SimCity, because even if the game is better, the business practices are just as, or maybe even WORSE than, EA's. You can't just excuse this sort of thing by saying it's a smaller dev and publisher. You can't let them get away with it because they have made a good game.This is greedy and, to me, inexcusable.If you make a game and try to profit off of acting better than EA, don't shoot yourself in the foot by continually showing that you are JUST as greedy as them.

title: Recommended
comment: A prime example of the benefits of PC gamingCities: Skylines is what happens when you develop a game without consoles in mind.✓ Fun and addictingHear me out: I've always avoided city building games like the plague because I thought they weren't my cup of tea. The free weekend came along and I thought "why not?"... look at my hours now.✓ 100% moddableSpecific buildings of all types, colors and flavors, intersections, maps, different lighting settings, gameplay-altering mods... just about anything can be found in the workshop. Be warned though: using mods disables achievements.✓ Fair learning curveYou might think a game like this is too complicated, but the truth is... it's not. Cities: Skylines is as complicated as you make it. Sure, if you're a beginner (like me), your first cities will fail, but that's exactly what makes this game so replayable: you learn by failing, and it's fun as hell.Rural town? Metropolis? European capital? Futuristic city? A replica of your town?As of now, they've released two expansions: After Dark and Snowfall. They'll release more, and that's good, but there's no way to buy a game+expansions pack, which means that no one knows the pricetag for the ultimate experience, and you might end up spending hundreds of euros in the game if they keep releasing expansions. You might think "how is that a problem? If they release more content, I'll happily pay". Well, look at . Would you pay 4,000€ for the full experience? I'm not saying Paradox will take the same route, but they could, and you should be wary.Cities: Skylines has quickly turned into one of my favorite games. I've always liked . This game is like having your own, but alive. I thoroughly recommend it.

title: Recommended
comment: I've just started, but since this just came out I want to help the guys and girls still on the fence. It reminds me Sim City 4, but with modern improvements! It is easy to play, and the game explains the core concepts as you go. This is the city builder that we have been waiting for. Click Add to cart, now.Before I describe the game, I have had absolutely no choppiness and I have the game maxed out. If you have a quality PC you should have no issues running this game.You have 9 different maps to choose from. There is no random map option, but there is an editor included that you can create your own maps or download maps from other players. So, you will always have new maps to play on.The game has a few interesting subsystems that work together. The more educated your citizens are, the less trash they will produce. Poorer the neighborhood will lead to more crime. You have to keep your pollution levels down or you could risk tainting the drinking water of your citizens.There are multiple road options to allow you to truly customize the shape and direction of your town.Do you want to build a eco friendly paradise or do you want to build the biggest city that you can? The game gives you the tools for you to decide. Also, with the editors available there should be plenty of options coming from other players.For the old timers who remember Sim City on the SNES (I know it was PC first, but back then a SNES was a few hundred dollars and PC's were $2,000 easy) for everytime you reach a population milestone you level up your ability to add items to your city.

title: Recommended
comment: Cities: Skylines and it's various expansion packs are the tale of an indie developer's dream to create a game that many would assume is impossible for a small group to work on. While it's a great game overall, it's not without it's faults.PROS:From the creators of Cities in Motion, I present to you one of the most elegant transit construction systems in the game. The base game comes with buses, trains, subways (metros), boats, and airplanes. The expansions have added thus far streetcars (trams), taxis, and a variety of emergency air vehicles. The new Mass Transit expansion will add blimps, ferries, monorails, and aerial tramways (cable cars). Building and upgrading roads is a SNAP!Asset creators let you replace vehicles, buildings, and props... Resulting in a massive modding community for a variety of content... Some of it being made by yours truly.CUSTOM MAPS. Do you prefer a city by the bay or the little town in the valley. Are you a fan of small maps like me? The map creator is perhaps the most impressive tool in this game, as it allows you to create virtually any city you want.CONS:From the creators of Cities in Motion, I present to you the most screwball vehicle pathfinding in the game. While buses and the other public vehicles seem pretty intelligent, it's the citizens who can't seem to figure out how to drive around town. Then again, this has been a problem that has plagued the city-builder since the days of 3D games.Many people often state that Cities: Skylines is the "real city-builder" to SimCity 2013... As some one who has played both games for a very long time, I honestly say they are two different games that show the ultimate problem of the city-building genre.But as for Skylines, let's just say that it is ultimately the "City Painter" of the two. This is not in a mocking tone; with the variety of assets you can create/find as well with a few mods, you can create whatever city you can dream of. There are so many features and means to this game, it's surprising to see how such a small dev-team can pull it off. The large amount of space on the maps means you can create much more realistic cities, or simply opt to create several smaller towns spread across the region (as I do myself). You could even, with a mod, take a ride in a car and see your city from a citizen's point of view... That's how artistic and crafty this game is.But it comes at a price... The overall depth really isn't there. While you do have some challenges and moments where the game does test you (Natural Disasters adds in some curve balls especially), there overall isn't going to be a lot that happens unless you get careless. There's no economic catastrophes, no global market where prices on oil can cause a crisis, and no real reward for educating citizens outside of cleaner factories... As far as "classic city-builder" goes, the game is just that, but if you want more depth and see the cause and effects of say, a casino opening up shop or what happens when housing is built down-wind from factories, the other city builder I mentioned does that better at the cost of content and some complexity. But alas, has there ever been a city-building game that truly focused on economic stability and social factors as opposed to growth and profit?Ultimately, as a contributor to the workshop and a fan of city-builders, I recommend this game in the end despite not truly going as in-depth as I want it to. Yes, it's a bit pricey, but if you really want to build the biggest city imaginable or take a spin down your own highway through your very own take on Blade Runner's Los Angeles, this game will deliver on those goods. The dev team is committed to this game, and it has a very active group of players who create a variety of stuff everyday.
