comment: I am and have always been a huge fan of simulation games. This game by far is the best SimCity game i have ever played - the interface of building is so much better as far as placement of roads, optional elevation - types of avenues, single lane and highways goes. They have come a along way since the first SimCity. the addition of districts is also super cool - now you can have a massive industrial area in the center of your city without creating a deadly amount of population. The addition of tourism options is also handy. I also really like the way they revamped the public transit structure - it is now way more effective and alot easier to use.I could go on and on about this game. Overall i give it a 11/10.absolutely love it.

title: Recommended
comment: Overview: A simcity killer that does everything right, plain and simple.Pros:-Beautifully simple and easy to learn interface. Took me about 5 minutes to figure out where everything was.-The "chirp" system of notifications is a really good way of bringing a realistic form of alerts into the game.-Tutorial is very helpful but not in the way if you already know what to do.-Map editor, asset editor, editor editor...-Endless community assets, mods, and addons-Beautiful looking and not hard to run on modern laptops.-There is an immense amount of depth to the game and it is simplified just enough to make it so youre always doing something, but youre never confused. It is always clear what you need to do, how to do it, and why.-You can rename anything and anyone, to anything you want.Cons:-A couple of bugs (that already have community fixes)-Roads can be a bit frustrating at time. However, updates are already rolling out concerning updating / downgrading them.-Intersections and redoing roadways when it becomes a high traffic area basically destroys any local economy based on those roadways. Wish there was a more efficent way of upgrading intersections themselves, rather than just having them prebuilt.Final verdict:If you've been looking for a city simulator that is fun, but simcity just didnt do it for you, then this game is for you.9/10

title: Recommended
comment: This game usurped the "best city builder" crown and title from Simcity, put it on, sat back on the throne, and is lording it. That's how I explained this game to all my friends. I loved Simcity 4, not so much the simplistic mess that was Simcity (2013). I love this game because it is more SC4 than Simcity (2013), and it is utterly gorgeous to boot.This game has all the micromangment I loved in SC4, and then some, coupled to an utterly beautiful engine that is not just gorgeous to look at, but it does what it needs to do. This game has a relatively well-working AI that actually makes transportation work. I am utterly in love with the planned routes.I really felt like my cities were alive, and what more, they were my cities. I could name my districts, my transport lines, some facilities, etc. The policies made tweaking everything just a joy. And when I am done tweaking an area, I can watch the city react almost instaneously. I can see the changes at work. For example, I can zoom in real close and see the impact of on pedestrian traffic of that new footpath I added. I can also sit back, and just cruise over my city and watch it just live.If you want a City builder that is like SimCity 4, except newer, this game is most definitely a heavy contender.

Decided to actually look at the DLC5. Noticed that I didn't actually want all the DLC6. Bought Mass Transit DLC7. 10/10 was a good DLC, but the game is also enjoyable without it.Good job, Paradox. You made a good city builder and have made good DLC to go with it, should anyone want some extra stuff. EA could learn a thing or two here.If you want a great city builder that will keep you entertained for a while, here it is. 10/10, would nominate for Mom's Spaghetti again.

comment: Cities Skylines is the game Sim City 5 should have been.Build a sprawling utopian metropolis built upon clean energy and renewable policies, or harvest the land for raw resources and build an industrial dystopia.Cities Skylines has recieved numerious DLC updates in which many of the gameplay improvements have been made availible to owners of the base game free of charge.This is the City management Sim you've wanted since Sim City 2000.

title: Recommended
comment: Cities: Skylines is the best city building game that I have played to date. Unlike any other that I have seen, the focus of Skylines is not on fine budget management, or clever zoning, but on traffic management. After your city gets on its feet and people start pouring in, you will spend the rest of the game designing elegant solutions to the gridlock that will plague your city- and slapdash fixes when that doesn't work. Money is rarely a problem, unless you screw up something major and leave everyone without power, or water, or over-educate all your cities and run out of workers, but this rarely happens. Every single citizen in your city has a home, and a job, and they need to be able to get from one to the other easily- no mean feat. When imports and exports are thrown into the mix, snarling traffic jams and clogged up roads further than the eye can see are inevitable.TL;DR This is one of my favourite games, it's definitely worth the full price of 30USD and is good for endless fun. I'm definitely putting a lot more hours into it.

title: Recommended
comment: I played almost every city building game you can imagine: each and every SimCity game (even SimCity Social and Societies, yuck), the Anno series aka Dawn of Discovery, Cities XL, Stronghold, Cities in Motion, Tropico, and even the really old stuff like Caesar or Pharaoh.You can imagine that I love these types of games!And let me tell you this - Cities: Skylines is easily the best city simulator in over 10 years, trust me. The base simulation and game polish is very solid, but with easy and well integrated mod support, the game is nothing short of phenomenal.And it's only 30 bucks. And was made by 13 people. Could someone pinch me?

title: Recommended
comment: As my playtime suggests, I do enjoy this game as I have spent countless hours on it - At first I was interested in effeciently handling the sims but now I spend half if not most of the time modifing aesthetics instead of functionality. The workshop adds a ton more functionality and content and is the main reason I still play this game.A few essentials mods would be 81 tiles, extra landscaping tools, network extentions, surface painter & props and search box. Most importantly of all, the mod "Move it!" allows you to use keyboard controls to move already existing roads and buildings inch by inch. If you are going to downlaod alot of custom assets - Id highly recommend getting "Loading screen mod" to see the progress on loading since with a heavy mod loadout, it can feel like the loading screen isnt doing nothing stock.

comment: This game has got to be the boss of building games. Great features, and a very active and friendly community. There are many ways to play this game and with the different DLC's there is a lot of variety available. I do think the dlc's are a bit overpriced when just released but buying them right away or waiting on sales is totally up to you.But, I am gonna add this even though it has nothing to do with the vanilla game; the steam workshop community is amazing but that in combination with the DLC's is eating on your performance. Just keep that in mind when you want to buy this game.I wish the traffic/ pathfinding of AI would be different/ better or more realistic but there are ways to work around it, or work with. In the end, this game is fantastic and has a lot to offer. If you like building/ simulation games and such and you don't have Cities: Skylines in your library than shame on you! I am sure I will have a lot more hours of fun playing this game than I already have so far.

title: Recommended
comment: This game is amazing. It has all the amazing aspects you would exect in a city building game, plus more. This game has everything that SimCity didn't. It's customizable roads and asset syestems make for very complex road systems, and very dense housing developments. The modding community is also gargantuant, with anything you could think of being in the workshop. However, I have two complaints about this game. The graphics and standard buildings are kinda ugly, compared to SimCity's gorgeous ones. I suppose they would look ok turned up to maximum, but you have to have a computer that is $1700+ for the game to not overload itself and crash. It's lag gets extreame whenever you get a town with over 10,000 people. This has limited me to only one computer I can access this on. So overall this game is great, BUT DONT BUY IF YOU DO NOT HAVE A $900+ COMPUTER.

title: Recommended
comment: Cities: Skylines is an improvement on the genre. If you are making the jump from Simcity 4 to Cities: Skylines, then you will be shocked by how much the road building; traffic simulation; and zoning have improved. Gone are the days of those rigid grid streets with cars being generated as you simply move the camera around. Gone are the days where plots have to be in a grid. You are free to build as you please, even weird shapes that look really ugly! Cars are persistent and try to reach fixed destinations that their drivers have (work, shopping, etc). You'll definitely never go back to Simcity 4 again, except maybe to blow up your cities.

title: Recommended
comment: There are some games that are completely addicting and force me to play for just another five minutes (which turns into hours). Cities: Skylines is one of those games. This game does what many city builders cannot. It has the feel of the Sim City series with just a few problems:-Traffic (4 and 6 lane roads are not helpful in most cases)-Not enough people per skyscraper building if you want realism. It's incredibly difficult (potentially impossible) to reach millions of people in your city-Not multiplayer and unable to attach your own cities together to create a bigger metropolis with more traffic issues (that was something that Sim City 4 still does well for singleplayer)Still the majority of the game is amazing fun with challenges to unlock important items for moving forward. I have no idea how many cities I have gone through and it still doesn't get old. It's a must have for anyone who enjoys a simulator.

title: Recommended
comment: An excellent city building sim to pick up where SimCity utterly failed. Excellent gameplay and beautiful assets make for a wonderful experience and its so easy to sink hours into this game and not even realize it. Definitely epitomizes the "just one more thing" addictive gameplay that keeps players engaged. There are some bugs in the game however and it needs to be said that traffic AI leaves ALOT to be desired and alot of time can be spent just working around the congestion caused by idiotic cars who only use one lane of a three lane road for five miles straight. Also the lack of multi track subway systems without a mod is a huge oversight. Mod are plentiful and theres literally over a hundred thousand different things in the workshop to suit any city situation. DLCs are getting a bit expensive for the amount of content they contain but the small size of the studio and the obvious love and effort they put into the base game make them an easy pill to swallow. Cities Skylines is all you want in a city building sim, amazing gameplay, great community support, and the ability to realize your craziest city dreams.... HIGHLY RECCOMMENDED

title: Recommended
comment: I am and have always been a huge fan of simulation games. This game by far is the best SimCity game i have ever played - the interface of building is so much better as far as placement of roads, optional elevation - types of avenues, single lane and highways goes. They have come a along way since the first SimCity. the addition of districts is also super cool - now you can have a massive industrial area in the center of your city without creating a deadly amount of population. The addition of tourism options is also handy. I also really like the way they revamped the public transit structure - it is now way more effective and alot easier to use.I could go on and on about this game. Overall i give it a 11/10.absolutely love it.

title: Recommended
comment: If you like this type of game, I would definitely recommend buying this one as it's the best city builder out there at the moment.As the previous person has already stated, the fact that anyone can add (and share) their own content (buildings, props, maps and even their saved games) to the game really gives it extra diversity which really does enhance an already great game. The developer is constantly updating it with new content and bug fixes which is great to see. Also, there are some great places where CS players can meet, discuss and share content/tips (Facebook groups, fan websites etc).I have since purchased both of the two updates which gives the game even more depth and options and I'm looking forward to see what comes next. This game is what most of us always wanted Sim City to be! :)Feel free to add me as a friend on the Steam system if you wish.

title: Recommended
comment: Overview: A simcity killer that does everything right, plain and simple.Pros:-Beautifully simple and easy to learn interface. Took me about 5 minutes to figure out where everything was.-The "chirp" system of notifications is a really good way of bringing a realistic form of alerts into the game.-Tutorial is very helpful but not in the way if you already know what to do.-Map editor, asset editor, editor editor...-Endless community assets, mods, and addons-Beautiful looking and not hard to run on modern laptops.-There is an immense amount of depth to the game and it is simplified just enough to make it so youre always doing something, but youre never confused. It is always clear what you need to do, how to do it, and why.-You can rename anything and anyone, to anything you want.Cons:-A couple of bugs (that already have community fixes)-Roads can be a bit frustrating at time. However, updates are already rolling out concerning updating / downgrading them.-Intersections and redoing roadways when it becomes a high traffic area basically destroys any local economy based on those roadways. Wish there was a more efficent way of upgrading intersections themselves, rather than just having them prebuilt.Final verdict:If you've been looking for a city simulator that is fun, but simcity just didnt do it for you, then this game is for you.9/10

comment: Love this game but there are a few SLIGHT flaws, I'll post the positives first;-Great, clean graphics. Nicer than the new sim city-Great variety of buildings, more than sim city-Smooth framerate(most of the time)-MASSIVE maps, I've never fully filled one out-Good hub menuBUT, the only bad thing I will say is sometimes there's a lack of explination for things, like when I have 'not enough goods to sell' I'd like the game to tell me a brief summary on how I would fix that. I don't need my hand held but a brief summary would've been great.That's the only bad thing I have to say, buy this game. You have more freedom than with sim city/.

title: Recommended
comment: This isn't a game I sound days upon days playing, but this is a game that no matter when you pick it up or how much time you have put into it, it still feels like a new city building experience. The base game comes with enough material that you wont even look at the DLC until you've put about 50 hours in, and they rejuvenate the game playing experience everytime. I was worried about the controls being hard to learn since my only previous experience with city builders was tropico and the Sim City franchise, but the game gives you freedom without throwing you to the wolves. When you first start, you have basic utilities, and you gain new amnenities as you progress in your city building, which allows you a chance to gain familiarity with the controls without the high risk pressure. Cities Skylines is a relaxing, complex, creative game well worth the price tag. 10/10 would recommend

I LOVE IT!

title: Not Recommended
comment: Changed my review from positive to negative because of the huge influx of DLC that came into the game in the past couple of years.It's basically become what Paradox does to most if not all their published games. This game has less of that issue because they "attempt" to cushion it with Free content with every major DLC update. However there are some key mechanics or issues that have risen because I haven't bought any of the DLC.One glarring issue I've come across since the After Dark DLC Update release is my Police Station's prison cells are becoming over crowded with prisoners! And I can't deal with my 60+ extra prisoners just "floating around somewhere??" just because I haven't bought the After Dark DLC so I can build Prisons tohouse them... If you're going to force me with this issue why wouldn't you provide prisons as the Free Update..?Another good example of the greedy business practices that publishers push onto the developers just to boost their profit and stocks... The only thing Publishers are good for is the funding and marketing, and they don't always even get that right...Unfortunately this is one of the best City Builders out there...Second place if not still the best is Sim City 4, only thing holding back SC4 from easily being top is it's age... SC4 had the charm/personality, fairly well built ecconomic system, multiple cities in one region.My Dream City Builder would be in my eyes, quite unsurprisingly: Cities Skylines and Sim City 4 crossed together.If Maxis (developers of SC4) had their own capital to dedicate their own modern city builder, and the full time neccesary to build the game they want. Maybe even have Colosal Order work alongside them in developing the game.Both Dev companies have a great idea of what a city builder is like but they both had a few things missing where the other company could fill in the gap.But.. Tis only but a dream that will most likely never come to fruition..Hopefully in the near future a true predecessor city builder will come out and blow these games out of the water....And let's just pretend that Sim City 2013 doesn't exist.

title: Recommended
comment: This is the first game I've ever reviewed on Steam. One of the first games I ever played was SimCity on MacOS 7 way back in the early 90's. I'm 30 years old. That may give you some perspective. SimCity2000 was the game that introduced gaming to my family, brother or sister, mother or father, along with Wolfenstein and Carmegeddon (weird, right?). Later on, my Dad and I played a bit of SimCity3000. I played a lot of SimCity4, including in the past year. There is a little bit of tradition here. Buy this game.That being said, there are some depth issues. While the game works intuitively, as you would imagine a city would, it doesn't have the depth of SimCity4 or SimCity2000. I won''t comment on SimCity3000 because I never played it to a significant extent. However, I believe the [already stated] intentions of the developer and the immediately incredible mod scene will ultimately make up for the lack of depth.That shouldn't affect your purchasing decision. This game is accessible and intuitive. Cities work exactly as expected. There are no interface or stability issues. Anyone who has an interest in the general (and I mean general) concept of villages/cities/towns will enjoy this game, from people interested in design to people interested in hardcore strategy games. Again, buy it.

title: Recommended
comment: After the recent SimCity turned out to be a massive flop, and Cities XXL being...well Cities XL reskinned, the city building genre pretty much looked dead and would probably share the fate of Maxis Studios.Then came Cities: Skylines.I enjoy Cities: Skylines because it's everything I ever wanted in a city builder, unrestrained building, and a virtual populace that actually interacts with the city you built. What that means is unlike Cities XL/XXL the cars and people aren't some visual, your people travel around the city to their jobs, go to places to relax, so on, and need to deal with the issues in between, like traffic.As for unrestrained building, with a bit of button presing and switch flipping you can tailor the game to however you want to play it. Even mod it if its not there already, Cities: Skylines does have a big modding scene.Now in game, you can set up your roads, bridges, tunnels, in anyway you want, make it crazy looking to fix traffic, or just see what you can do for fun, set up building next to it, you got low/high residental, low/high commercial, industrial, a good amount of city planning is involved.You can plan for tourism, traffic fluidity, making everyone happy, typical mainstays of the city builder, long story short, Cities: Skylines is by far the best city builder to have come out recently, I fully recommend it and its expansions.

comment: This game is amazing. It has all the amazing aspects you would exect in a city building game, plus more. This game has everything that SimCity didn't. It's customizable roads and asset syestems make for very complex road systems, and very dense housing developments. The modding community is also gargantuant, with anything you could think of being in the workshop. However, I have two complaints about this game. The graphics and standard buildings are kinda ugly, compared to SimCity's gorgeous ones. I suppose they would look ok turned up to maximum, but you have to have a computer that is $1700+ for the game to not overload itself and crash. It's lag gets extreame whenever you get a town with over 10,000 people. This has limited me to only one computer I can access this on. So overall this game is great, BUT DONT BUY IF YOU DO NOT HAVE A $900+ COMPUTER.

title: Recommended
comment: The game is fun and certainly complex, and by using mods you can custiomize the gameplay to suit your style. You can play it as a sim-game or with a more casual approach.It has its flaws though: traffic management could certainly be improved, and once you reach a certain point the game kinda stalls because there is not much more to do. If you enjoy planning and designing you will enjoy how the game plays, but there are no objectives to complete, neither missions or scenarios.A lot of new content has been added with updates and DLCs, and the game seems to have at least a few years of support.I strongly recommend it if you like city building and relaxing for a while.

title: Recommended
comment: I used to adore the city builder and similar games of the past. So many hours of Sim City, Settlers, Colonization (okay, maybe not so much that one). To be honest I got completely tired of each iteration being pretty much 90% the same game witha just a few twists and better graphics.Then came Cities: Skylines. I absolutely adore everything about this game; even the 'bugs'. Which aren't even really bugs, just hilarious little happenings of the people and animals within my cities.What makes this game so great? The community. So many wonderful mods, the fantastic support of the dev team (Long live TotalyMoo!), and a game where you can get completely lost in the tiniest little details without feeling pressured by the game nagging you... (*ignores Chirpy*).

title: Recommended
comment: This is the game SimCity should have been.I got a small twinge of anxiety when I saw that the plot of land you start with was just as small as it is in said SimCity, but then I played the game a bit and realized you can actually expand the area later on by buying land, and your first land upgrade comes early on. The game makes your goals and milestones very clear. There are no conflicting messages, and the mechanics of the game are well explained. Especially nice is the "relocate building" button, so if you make a huge mistake, or just change your mind down the line, you aren't stuck bulldozing something ridiculously expensive. Even better, the price of the game itself is extremely fair.Fans of City Simulators will love it. While SimCity was full of all sorts of little things that wore away at your patience, Cities: Skylines has all sorts of little things that endear you to it and immerse you. Couldn't recommend it more.

comment: I got this game yesterday, and I must say that I am extremely impressed. To say that this game exceeded my expectations is an understatement. This is what SimCity should have been! I hope you are reading this Maxis. You have ALLOT to learn from these guys. The design, the concept, the artwork are superior. One of the best things about the game is the obvious respect for the player. There is a full editor mode that allows players to create maps contents and MODs. Yup, that's right! The only thing that I wish for are libraries and museums. I can't wait to see what they do next. Thanks for an excellent city building game.

title: Recommended
comment: The best city-sim I have played in a long time!It has:an in-depth traffic system (traffic flow could use some tweaks but still good)Dynamic water flow and dam systemsGiant city sizes (especially with mods)Day one mod supportIn my opinion detailed and nice graphicsAmazing value for moneyCan render vast amounts of people cars etc even on pretty bad pcsEvery single car, person, and pet has a home and workplace and is simulatedMap editorAsset editor for custom plobbable in game interchanges and parksLeft and right hand drive opitionsNo always online *glares at simcity cover*detailed transport system but can be hard to tweakOverall I say you go and buy this game right now!Oh and no EA interferance to ruin the game so enjoy!

comment: This is what SimCity 2013 was supposed to be, and more! It's not at all a perfect city builder, but it's by far the best city builder I've played.Great support for mods and player-made content, that helps working around the small kinks, especially when it comes to traffic managment, which is the most difficult to handle in the vanilla game when you start getting a city of notable size.

title: Recommended
comment: Everything in Cities: Skylines is great and works great! BUT, it REALLY Needs a lot more village / small town assets - not everybody loves major urban metro. A ski resport / log cabin / mountain town expansion is needed. Not all the world is flat. Coal mining town assets, more rural assets in general. MOST of planet Earth is sparse, rural community areas. Also, the addition of lots of Sci-Fi assets would be great - future town stuff, Caprica City stuff, Firefly, Star Trek, Star Wars, anything / any franchise. Also wasteland, capital wasteland, new vegas, fallout assets, and of course Skyrim maps and villages. Cities: Towns and Villages - with horse and buggy traffic, Amish expansion pack, camels and bicycles, overall - a great game, I just wish it had more variety of era / time frame... and of course after building a horse drawn buggy village, drop a Blue Box in a small corner, with a man and a lady that wander around that area...

title: Recommended
comment: This always looked like an interesting game to me ever since it was released. I ended up purchasing the game and so far has been a very good time waster. Very addicting. The game has such a large amount of content, this includes workshop content to DLC. This ensures many hours of gameplay with a different experience each time you play. People always make the complaint, The DLC content is too expensive. I agree with this, however the amount of content in the base game + steamworkshop is more than enough to cater for anyone wanting a city builder simulator.Pros-Mods and Workshop content add many hours of unique gameplay-A large range of content in the vanilla game-UI and mechanics are in depth but user friendly.Cons- DLC is expenisve however the devs have done alot of work on the improvement of this game, therefore support to them is the least we can do to continue the development of the game!

title: Recommended
comment: It's simple: This game is exactly what Simcity 5 should have been. While it's not perfect, the gripes about the game's issues are fairly small and petty when the simulation itself is slick and easily modded. This game learned from SC5's shortfalls and vastly improved on itself. AAA game at a great price.

comment: This game is fantastic.You have full control. You have all the freedom in the world (although you still have to stay within guidelines).The modding community is vast and creative, there's a mod for everything.The only critique is the A.I.They are incredibly stupid.The traffic is god awful at an intersection because the A.I. can't seem to figure out that there is an extra lane, free.The only problem I'm having with my city is that I build faster than the city can keep up. I build an entire district, but since they have all they need, I have to wait for them to populate the area.And that's it! Those are only real problems I have.I seriously reccomend this.p.s. title: Recommended
comment: I'm going to edit my review since I don't think my previous one was that good.In Cities: Skylines, you can build cities. It's pretty realistic: you have to deal with traffic issues and what not, you have to build fire stations so your buildings don't burn down, you have to build cemeteries and crematoriums, etc.Overall, the game is very good, but what makes it even better is the Steam Workshop support. Without mods, I wouldn't have gotten the 67 hours I have logged on it as of time of writing. There's mods for basically everything. You can install mods so you'll have lots more of building varieties, you can add landmarks to your city, you can have a gigantic statue of a hamster if you want, there's mods to change the color of your roads or even Americanize them if you want.. As of recently, you can even mod VEHICLES: I can now see DeLoreans driving my city.And you can install a mod... with one click. You don't need any dragging & dropping folders, etc. like for other games like GTA IV.The developers are very great as well. They listen to their community and they are very active.This game was very well worth it in my opinion.

title: Recommended
comment: A breath of fresh air after EA's awful, restrictive SimCity 2013, Cities: Skylines delivers everything that city builder fans expect and deserve:- HUGE cities- Incredible depth and detail in its game systems- Endless customisation and ways to express your planning, design and creativity- A learning curve that ramps up organically as your city grows and becomes more complex- Fantastic developer support- A thriving mod community- Great value, even at full price- No always-online DRM or pay-to-win microtransaction shenanigansHands down the best city building sim available right now.Update: For the Steam awards. This game is still great, and even better value with the current sale.

title: Recommended
comment: Cities: Skylines is an amazing new take on the city-building genre. I played SimCity, and didn't like where EA took that series after Will Wright left Maxis. I was really hoping that the SimCity would capture that same look and feel of the best game in the series, SimCity 4, and while updating the old ways and making them better, but sadly, even with all the improvements in graphics and different gameplay elements, SimCity did not feel like a true successor. That's where Cities: Skylines shines.As soon as I started up the game and got to the main menu, I enjoyed what it had to offer. Cities: Skylines feels very new and unique in it's own way. It's doing it's own thing with city-building, and it doesn't feel like a ripoff. It's very easy to play and learn, and that's one thing I like about it. I can jump in my city at any time and start up where I left off with ease, and it runs pretty smoothly as well.Another thing I like about the developers is that they keep releasing content for the game, and I find their support of their game superb. I never have felt like I got that with EA's games. Even with Spore, there were a couple DLC packs and then that was that. No more support for another great game that could have been even better with further support from Maxis. The developers at Colossal Order Ltd. are very supportive and helpful when it comes to playing Cities: Skylines. I'm happy with the final product, and even happier that they choose to further support their game by releasing new expansions and updates to improve upon the base game, and finally, the fact that user-made content is appreciated and encouraged by the developers themselves. That is a huge plus in my eyes.I rate this game 5/5, 10/10, and 100/100. Very good work, Colossal Order Ltd.. Keep it up!

title: Recommended
comment: "Cities: Skylines" is a game about building and managing a player created city/town/village/megapolis/etc. . It's a complete sandbox with great support from the Steam Workshop. The community creations only give even more detail to the already great game.It also features a map making tool/mode, that invites a large portion of players to add and share their creations on the workshop.There are minor gripes I, personally, have, such as the ability to disable traffic lights or improve the driver AI, for example. But wait, the unlimited support from the modding community HAS made it possible!So, in the end, I rate this game with a 9/10, the only major problem being the simplistic AI, that can ruin a trully great city, if for some reason your mods suddenly stop existing.

title: Recommended
comment: This game was the answer to my questions. Long after SimCity 4 has fallen by the wayside and it's processing limitations become glaring, this game rose to save my sanity.Many people will claim this is more of a sandbox rather than a difficult city building game; while that may be true, I think it is in fact plenty difficult. Most, if not all of your time will be probably be spent managing that godawful traffic. Learn the ways of the roundabout and the one-way street, and those problems can be conquered. Intersections are evil.Pros:+Large play area+Realistic graphics+Realistic simulations+Runs relatively well on older systems (see below)+Allows nearly-infinte city customization+Hydro dams!+Tons of mods to fix many game problems+Allows you to create your own vehicle/building assetsCons:-Dumb traffic AI-Pollution is too friendly-Street planning can be a nightmare due to lack of advanced tools-Eats RAM like there's no tomorrowIf you're a micromanaging SOB who hates drag-and-drop automatic games and wants to create graceful curving traffic systems, this is for you. If you still cling to your SimCity 2000 CD like it's a matter of life and death, you better get this game. If you're still playing SimCity BuildIt on your 2010 tablet, you probably aren't ready for this.

title: Recommended
comment: I played almost every city building game you can imagine: each and every SimCity game (even SimCity Social and Societies, yuck), the Anno series aka Dawn of Discovery, Cities XL, Stronghold, Cities in Motion, Tropico, and even the really old stuff like Caesar or Pharaoh.You can imagine that I love these types of games!And let me tell you this - Cities: Skylines is easily the best city simulator in over 10 years, trust me. The base simulation and game polish is very solid, but with easy and well integrated mod support, the game is nothing short of phenomenal.And it's only 30 bucks. And was made by 13 people. Could someone pinch me?

comment: As my playtime suggests, I do enjoy this game as I have spent countless hours on it - At first I was interested in effeciently handling the sims but now I spend half if not most of the time modifing aesthetics instead of functionality. The workshop adds a ton more functionality and content and is the main reason I still play this game.A few essentials mods would be 81 tiles, extra landscaping tools, network extentions, surface painter & props and search box. Most importantly of all, the mod "Move it!" allows you to use keyboard controls to move already existing roads and buildings inch by inch. If you are going to downlaod alot of custom assets - Id highly recommend getting "Loading screen mod" to see the progress on loading since with a heavy mod loadout, it can feel like the loading screen isnt doing nothing stock.

comment: This game is quite tough to put down. Between the massive build area and countless maps in the workshop (not to mention the mods, dear god), this thing can keep anyone with a hint of creativity busy for quite literally hundreds of hours. I've put together a couple maps of more than a hundred thousand people, countless towns with painful amounts of detail, and, of course, I've flooded each and every one of those cities when the opportunity came by. Cities: Skylines is not fun in of itself -- the game is tool, much like Maya or Photoshop, that you use to create art. Whether that happens to be a dystopian highway-fest or a place you wouldn't mind calling home, this game is entertaining because it turns pen-and-paper sketches of unreal metropolises into life.TL;DR: Don't get this unless you're eager to slave over optimal grid/freeform layout designs for hours on end.

title: Recommended
comment: UPDATE: A month in and the game remains a delight. Great job, devs.Feels like what Simcity 2013 was meant to be. Easy to pick up, lots of options for complexity, and for me, a fun way to finally build an interesting city without the need for financial constraints - unless I want them. Huge cities are possible and a very nice sense of a living community (especially if you slow things down with one of the mods already out there). With the exception of some weak AA and ambient sounds varying between dull and infurating (those accursed sirens!!!), well worth the $30 price tag, especially knowing that patches and mods will make it even better.Update: After a few weeks playing, I see a growing number of simulation purists starting to beat on the game. I can respect that if they are seeking pure sim engine. But for me, opening the game up with no budget restrictions and logical (if not mind-bending challenges) means I can at last build a MY cities. Actually DESIGN them and while my errors are clear if I screw up, I can work it out and fix it without the sense of fighting the game and losing to a mistake I made hours before. This is just a plain fun and good-looking game with the best "alive" feeling I have seen. Mods can make the graphics look really nice and I for one can say this is the best $30 I have spent in a very long time.PS: I am still finding myself grinning like a kid at some things and saying "now that's great!" Have you clicked on a seagul and flown it? Buy the game, stuff it full of mods, and build a beautiful city where God doesn't hate you, people live their lives happily, cops don't shoot people, and folks aren't ♥♥♥♥♥ing and rioting on you evey five minutes.What would I change? The ambient sound. It's repetitive and the sirens are very aggrevating. But I am sure that we be moddable, soon enough.

comment: I got this game yesterday, and I must say that I am extremely impressed. To say that this game exceeded my expectations is an understatement. This is what SimCity should have been! I hope you are reading this Maxis. You have ALLOT to learn from these guys. The design, the concept, the artwork are superior. One of the best things about the game is the obvious respect for the player. There is a full editor mode that allows players to create maps contents and MODs. Yup, that's right! The only thing that I wish for are libraries and museums. I can't wait to see what they do next. Thanks for an excellent city building game.

Just keep that in mind when you want to buy this game.I wish the traffic/ pathfinding of AI would be different/ better or more realistic but there are ways to work around it, or work with. In the end, this game is fantastic and has a lot to offer. If you like building/ simulation games and such and you don't have Cities: Skylines in your library than shame on you! comment: It's a smashing game, it really is. title: Recommended
comment: Cities: Skylines is, in lack of a better description, a super Sim City. Even in the game's community the inhabitants are referred to as "cims" (instead of "sims").When creating and growing cities, at first the challenge is about budgeting but soon the biggest challenge is about functionality - whether creating new neighbourhoods intelligently or micro-managing the ones that already exist. The ammount of micro-managing, especially traffic, is inversely proportional to the thought you put into creating new neighbourhoods.The game fools you into thinking "hey, this is easy, i keep an eye on demands and create what they need and the city grows" but then, when you notice, you have sick citizens because of pollution, burned down buildings because the fireman can't reach the fires, traffic jams that don't allow people to go to work or, even if they do, don't allow cargo trucks to keep the economy working, etc.One thing is for sure, after some hours playing this game, you will think about your own town's city planning whenever you go out and drive.

comment: This isn't a game I sound days upon days playing, but this is a game that no matter when you pick it up or how much time you have put into it, it still feels like a new city building experience. The base game comes with enough material that you wont even look at the DLC until you've put about 50 hours in, and they rejuvenate the game playing experience everytime. I was worried about the controls being hard to learn since my only previous experience with city builders was tropico and the Sim City franchise, but the game gives you freedom without throwing you to the wolves. When you first start, you have basic utilities, and you gain new amnenities as you progress in your city building, which allows you a chance to gain familiarity with the controls without the high risk pressure. Cities Skylines is a relaxing, complex, creative game well worth the price tag. 10/10 would recommend

comment: This is the game SimCity should have been.I got a small twinge of anxiety when I saw that the plot of land you start with was just as small as it is in said SimCity, but then I played the game a bit and realized you can actually expand the area later on by buying land, and your first land upgrade comes early on. The game makes your goals and milestones very clear. There are no conflicting messages, and the mechanics of the game are well explained. Especially nice is the "relocate building" button, so if you make a huge mistake, or just change your mind down the line, you aren't stuck bulldozing something ridiculously expensive. Even better, the price of the game itself is extremely fair.Fans of City Simulators will love it. While SimCity was full of all sorts of little things that wore away at your patience, Cities: Skylines has all sorts of little things that endear you to it and immerse you. Couldn't recommend it more.

title: Recommended
comment: TL;DR: Bye bys Sim City. Cities Skylines has come to claim the throne of citybuilders, with success but not without (small) flaws.As the name suggests and as I have already said, Cities Skylines is a citybuilder. You start as a mayor of an empty plot of land next to a highway with lush green meadows, hills and rivers. You don't have a task, but you can build the city of your dreams. You build streets, organize public transportations and city services and designate zones for residential, commerce and industry next to streets.So far, so standard. but other games like Sim City or Cities XXL does the same. It doesn't take long to discover the first thing which makes this game special. You don't start with a full tech tree. Instead you start pretty limited and expand as the city grows in size. In addition to just building your city, you can also designate districts where special policies can be applied like modifying tax rates or issue water saving orders. These zones are especially important for industrial zones because you can assign farmland, timber industry or exhaustible resources like oil and ores. That means you don't build special buildings for these ores, just tax private industries, a clear improvement to Sim City.As the city grows, traffic starts to become a problem. Luckily, you have more than enough tools to deal with that problem. Instead of just building two way roads, you can also build one way roads and highways as well as public transportations. You can also expand your territory from Sim City size of 4km³ up to 36km³, with mods even 100km³. The graphics aren't especially beautiful, but it makes fun zooming in to watch how your city grows from a few houses at a gravel road to a busy metropolis full of skyscrapers.Sadly there is one thing that pisses me off. Colossal Order added a feature they call chirper. citizens of regularly send you messages via this in-game twitter ripoff to tell you how much they like the city or tell you if a house is missing a city service. This might be a good idea, but it gets annoying, and worst of all, you can't turn it off. Please CO, make an option to turn that fat blue bird off.Even if chirper is annoying, the game itself is great for a more than reasonable price of less than 30 Euro for the standard edition. I clearly recommend this this game for all city builder fans and strategy enthusiasts, all everyone who got disappointed by EA's Sim City 2013

title: Recommended
comment: I was very sceptical at the time about buying yet another city builder because all the previous ones failed my expectations (most of the miserably) and I regretted spending the money. But this a game is the opposite!This game is absolutely amazing. The base game is O.K. but with a very limited number of models for everything it gets boring to even look at very soon - and I think the devs knew that because that's where the best feature of this game comes in - Steam Workshop integration. The community is so amazing that we have hundreds of mods, at least 30 that I'd call indispensable, and tens of thousands of custom assets to choose from. I personally have about 1200 subscriptions on Workshop. That's how good they are.There also have been a couple DLCs. Personally I think, that they don't bring nearly enough on their own to warrant their full price BUT because each of then opens new possibilities for the mod and asset creators it makes them worth so much more... So if you plan on buying DLCs, buy them for the Workshop content they allow you to use :DIf you ever felt like you would enjoy designing a city then this game is definitely for YOU :)

title: Recommended
comment: After the recent SimCity turned out to be a massive flop, and Cities XXL being...well Cities XL reskinned, the city building genre pretty much looked dead and would probably share the fate of Maxis Studios.Then came Cities: Skylines.I enjoy Cities: Skylines because it's everything I ever wanted in a city builder, unrestrained building, and a virtual populace that actually interacts with the city you built. What that means is unlike Cities XL/XXL the cars and people aren't some visual, your people travel around the city to their jobs, go to places to relax, so on, and need to deal with the issues in between, like traffic.As for unrestrained building, with a bit of button presing and switch flipping you can tailor the game to however you want to play it. Even mod it if its not there already, Cities: Skylines does have a big modding scene.Now in game, you can set up your roads, bridges, tunnels, in anyway you want, make it crazy looking to fix traffic, or just see what you can do for fun, set up building next to it, you got low/high residental, low/high commercial, industrial, a good amount of city planning is involved.You can plan for tourism, traffic fluidity, making everyone happy, typical mainstays of the city builder, long story short, Cities: Skylines is by far the best city builder to have come out recently, I fully recommend it and its expansions.

title: Recommended
comment: I purchased the game today and I haven't stopped playing until now. I've just taken a short break and I decided that I might as well write a review so that I can help spread the word about the greatness that is this game. The fun thing about simcity (not this game obviously) was that I could build chains and make profit that way. Since I haven't seen that specific feature in this game and if my information is correct it isn't in this game at all, I thought that it might decrease my enjoyment of this game.That is not true. In fact, I had intended to wait until the game would go into a sale and then I would purchase it, but I was watching a let's play and I was thinking several times through the let's play episode, man I could do better then this guy. Then I thought, why not go and prove it? If only to myself.I still had some money on my steam wallet from my birthday in februari and I decided -after watching a few more video's just to be sure- that yes, this game is worth the purchase.So I bought the game, downloaded and installed it and like I said in the beginning of my review. I haven't stoppe playing since.I'm going to update this review when I have more hours under my belt and since no game can be perfect, I'm going to be updating this review with what negative points I can find.That said, so far I definetly recommend purchasing this game because you won't regret it for a moment. But if you have any doubts then just watch a couple of let's plays or look for a live stream so you can ask things there to show specific things and specific times.KingdarkEdit: 15/03/2015I realize that this edit is VERY near the time I originally posted the review, but I feel it's worth it. I'm amazed just how EASY it is to make money. Once you get going and get a feel for the system, I had just over a million credits which takes me LOTS longer when I play simcit. Hell, I always go bankrupt with simcity. Seriously.I finally decided I had to take a break because the way I built the city was bad. It is / was my first game and I'm reluctant to just scrap it. My savegame is up for grabs, if you like to try yourself. Anyway, my opinion has not changed and I am of the firm opinion that the game is still worth it and I'm sure that this will not change anytime soon.The only bad thing is that the mods should be monitored more carefully because one of the mods is in turkish or a langauge that is not english or in a scrip I recognize and it should be properly marked.Kingdark

title: Recommended
comment: Cities: Skylines is an amazing city builder. I haven't playes a Sim city game in a long time, admittedly, but Cities: Skylines really brings the genre to the forefront.The logic to this game is very good, where every peice of traffic or people actually has something to do, rather than just being cosmetic. This does make things a bit trickier, but overall that is much more fun. Similarly, the mechanics of district zoning is something I hadn't expected, but turns out to be really useful.Things do tend to get a bit hectic when you end up with a large population [>100,000], but that may just be due to my own lack of experience.The audio graphical design to this game are really good. It makes it a joy to just sink in to playing for hours. From a wide angle view of the environment, right down to the models of buildings and vehicles it all looks and sounds great. The interface isn't overly complex or cluttered, and it is easy to learn.The modding community to this game is amazing as well, with loads of great content. The devs are even taking hints from various popular mods and integrating relevant additions into the game itself, which is always nice to see. That, and the few gripes I do have about the game [like no tree brushes] can easily be fixed by a mod. They install easily, and I haven't had any game breakages from them.This game is definitely worth buyng if you like city builders, or simulator games of any kind.

title: Recommended
comment: For some reason I didn't think I was gonna like this game, but I picked it up for £6 in the sale and now I can't stop playing it. It's really good. Starts off slowly and then becomes increasingly difficult as your city grows and you have to add more stuff to keep things ticking over. Currently having problems with transport but there's heaps of guides on YouTube (Imperial Jedi is easy to watch and learn from and he knows his stuff, and I'm about to use an industrial park plan created by a guy called Akruas which I'm hoping will fix my gridlock). Once I've unlocked all the achievement buildings and monuments I'll be downloading some mods and starting a brand new, even better city with all the tips and tricks I've picked up along the way, and I've also added all the DLC to my wishlist so I've got hundreds of hours more entertainment yet to come.Would spend hours shouting at pleb cims and cursing their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ driving logic again (and again...) 10/10

title: Recommended
comment: This game usurped the "best city builder" crown and title from Simcity, put it on, sat back on the throne, and is lording it. That's how I explained this game to all my friends. I loved Simcity 4, not so much the simplistic mess that was Simcity (2013). I love this game because it is more SC4 than Simcity (2013), and it is utterly gorgeous to boot.This game has all the micromangment I loved in SC4, and then some, coupled to an utterly beautiful engine that is not just gorgeous to look at, but it does what it needs to do. This game has a relatively well-working AI that actually makes transportation work. I am utterly in love with the planned routes.I really felt like my cities were alive, and what more, they were my cities. I could name my districts, my transport lines, some facilities, etc. The policies made tweaking everything just a joy. And when I am done tweaking an area, I can watch the city react almost instaneously. I can see the changes at work. For example, I can zoom in real close and see the impact of on pedestrian traffic of that new footpath I added. I can also sit back, and just cruise over my city and watch it just live.If you want a City builder that is like SimCity 4, except newer, this game is most definitely a heavy contender.

title: Recommended
comment: Hey you! Ever wanted a game that is better then Sim City and is addicting? Do you also want to download mods by clicking a simple button? Then this game is for you!Anyways, jokes aside, this game is honestly AMAZING. Its a lot better then that sh!t Sim City, and alot more addicting. This game is really great, and I would seriously recommend this awesome game to you.Onto the Cons and Pros.Pros:After Dark; After Dark is a DLC, but the day and night cycle is free. Once you expand and make your city huge, the night will make it shine more, and make it more beautiful.Highly Addicting; This game is seriously addicting, you will have 10+ hours on this game, trust me.Highly Fun; This game is seriously fun. The mods keeps the game going, and mods also make it even way more fun.Challenging; This game is challenging, with traffic, and demands, this game will make you keep on playing non-stop.Highly Detailed; If you buy this game, I highly recommend you get the first person mod. If you download this, and go in first person, you will see that the civs are highly detailed. With them holding tablets, phones, having watches, and much more. The devs really did put a lot of care and love into this game.Cons:Intel Not Supported; I have a Intel i5 and this game lags alot for me. I read some forums, and apperantly this game doesnt support Intel's. You can still play it, but good luck.Glitches; Sometimes, this game glitches. Like for example, you have 10 incinerators, but your city still says you need to build more. Sometimes the garbage trucks doesn't even go to the building that needs a garbage truck.Conclusion:So, in conclusion, this game is highly fun and addicting, but sometimes glitches. We'll have to wait until they fix the glitches. Anyways, I highly recommend this game to you, and your friends. You will have alot of fun building your city, and will play non-stop. Thank you for reading, and keep building, Mayor!Like this review? Why not check out my other reviews? And why not thumbs up this review? Thanks for reading, and have a wonderful day.

comment: There are some games that are completely addicting and force me to play for just another five minutes (which turns into hours). Cities: Skylines is one of those games. This game does what many city builders cannot. It has the feel of the Sim City series with just a few problems:-Traffic (4 and 6 lane roads are not helpful in most cases)-Not enough people per skyscraper building if you want realism. It's incredibly difficult (potentially impossible) to reach millions of people in your city-Not multiplayer and unable to attach your own cities together to create a bigger metropolis with more traffic issues (that was something that Sim City 4 still does well for singleplayer)Still the majority of the game is amazing fun with challenges to unlock important items for moving forward. I have no idea how many cities I have gone through and it still doesn't get old. It's a must have for anyone who enjoys a simulator.

title: Recommended
comment: I've played this game a little bit now. I'll give you the tl;dr here: if you're an organization/planning nerd like me and you don't mind a somewhat steep learning curve, you'll probably love Cities: Skylines. If not, you will probably find this game absolutely infuriating.Pros:-UI is tidy and easy to use (once you learn how to use it--more on that later)-Constant new challenges as your city expands (or as it fails, depending on how okay a mayor you are)-Beautiful graphics-Soothing soundtrack-Realistic ebb and flow of population etc.-Ability to micromanage almost everything in the city (although managing individual intersections or buildings is not a thing unless you nab some DLC)Cons:-No tutorial built into the game, besides the little "hi there, please build a road" blurb you get at the beginning. I think I started three different cities and trial-and-errored them into oblivion before I finally broke down and found a few game guides.-There are, in theory, 25 tiles available for purchase, but you can only purchase 9 of them unless you mod. While that is probably a bit of a pro for some people because of the challenge, it's a con for me because I prefer to expand copiously. There's also no indication that this is the case until you buy 9 tiles and can suddenly not purchase any more. (Also note that if you mod it so you can buy more tiles, you can no longer obtain any achievements. I don't care about that much, but for those who do, I imagine this would be frustrating, although understandable from a dev's perspective.)-The inability to directly manage buildings, while certainly realistic, can be extremely aggravating. For example, I sometimes have had giant waves of death sweep my city and the cemeteries and crematoriums (totally a word) will be sending out like 2/10 available hearses, despite the constant messages I'm getting about how dead bodies are piling up everywhere. I've found that placing a crematorium right next to a cemetery mostly solves this problem, but it's still a bit ridiculous, and you can't do anything about it with, say, policies.In total, 8/10 I play this game far more frequently than is probably healthy. Beware the siren call of city planning.

title: Recommended
comment: This is one of those games which falls under the "easy to learn, difficult to master" categories. I picked it up on sale, and during the first few hours it really did a good job of showing me the ropes. The mechanics, interface and design are all intuitive. Yes, with time you realize additional menus that make things even better, but the game is definitely easier to pick up on then some other simulators out there (I’m looking at you planet coaster). Visually, the game is very pleasing.Within a few hours my city had grown to a respectable size. Little did know what troubles were in store for me! one word.... TRAFFIC...... I made some poor design choices when placing my roads. Couple that with poor placement of industry, commercial zones too many high rise residential areas. ineffective public transport system and you have the ingredients for a disaster. Traffic became so bad that my services couldn’t get around to clearing out garbage, putting out fires, moving the dying, fighting crime and so on. People started to move out and the next milestone of my cities growth was out of reach (mile stones unlock additional tech for your city i.e. better power plants, new buildings, trains, airplanes, etc...). I went back to the drawing board, did some research on road design, interchanges and started to build a better city next time round.What makes this game even more fantastic is the wonderful community. Tons of videos and guides are out there to help you and give you new perspectives. Additionally, the modding community has developed some wonderful material for this game. Some of it is a must for when you play. For example, mods for additional bus designs or new car types, or different buildings. Or pre-created interchanges to save you time building them yourself. I advise you do some research into the best mods and utilize them to make your experience even better.

title: Recommended
comment: This is the game SimCity should have been.I got a small twinge of anxiety when I saw that the plot of land you start with was just as small as it is in said SimCity, but then I played the game a bit and realized you can actually expand the area later on by buying land, and your first land upgrade comes early on. The game makes your goals and milestones very clear. There are no conflicting messages, and the mechanics of the game are well explained. Especially nice is the "relocate building" button, so if you make a huge mistake, or just change your mind down the line, you aren't stuck bulldozing something ridiculously expensive. Even better, the price of the game itself is extremely fair.Fans of City Simulators will love it. While SimCity was full of all sorts of little things that wore away at your patience, Cities: Skylines has all sorts of little things that endear you to it and immerse you. Couldn't recommend it more.

comment: Absolutely outstanding! Would definitely reccomend over any other city building game, it is a pleasure to play and gives you unlimited controls over realistic-looking cities. It has an extended workshop with mods, assets, maps and themes (etc.) straight from the community. Has very good graphics. The 'traffic' could, however, be somehow improved as can cause a problem at times, though I think that the game is absolutely wonderful nevertheless.

title: Recommended
comment: I've dropped over 500 hours into C:SL since its purchase. While I play it a bit less now in favor of a lot of hacking and slashing and looting all of the things, it's not a knock against the city builder in any way.It's the kind of game I can sit down with, play for a few hours, and enjoy dealing with the city building and the chaos that can come with it, whether it's a poorly planned interchange, a surprise flood in a scenario, or goodness knows what else.I was looking for a city builder after getting burned not once, but twice on CitiesXL and its ilk, and at that time, this game was new and had promise. I've lost entire weekends to crazy city builds, and I'm not sorry for that time lost.

comment: By far the best city-builder I have ever played. It's all the magic of Sim-City with the perks of a brand-new game, a modding community, and producers who are willing to work witht he community to add additional content and fix current.10/10Already neglecting life to play it.Oh, and it's not made by EA, so there's a bonus. You don't need to be online to play it, there's no microtransation nonsense. No strings attached, like games are meant to be.PS. Be careful when building dams. I built one upstream of my waste output pipes and because there was another branch in the river, all i did was block the current. The waste water then backed up to my water intakes, and the entire population started to get sick. Next thing I know, I'm out of money, the city's infastructure has collapsed, I'm going into debt, and and I can't fix the water issues because I have no money.Needless to say, I accidentally created Detroit.

The shear amount of fantastic (almost must-have) mods is amazing!TLDR: do you love city-building games? Instant buy!

title: Recommended
comment: "Cities: Skylines" is a game about building and managing a player created city/town/village/megapolis/etc. . It's a complete sandbox with great support from the Steam Workshop. The community creations only give even more detail to the already great game.It also features a map making tool/mode, that invites a large portion of players to add and share their creations on the workshop.There are minor gripes I, personally, have, such as the ability to disable traffic lights or improve the driver AI, for example. But wait, the unlimited support from the modding community HAS made it possible!So, in the end, I rate this game with a 9/10, the only major problem being the simplistic AI, that can ruin a trully great city, if for some reason your mods suddenly stop existing.

title: Recommended
comment: This game was the answer to my questions. Long after SimCity 4 has fallen by the wayside and it's processing limitations become glaring, this game rose to save my sanity.Many people will claim this is more of a sandbox rather than a difficult city building game; while that may be true, I think it is in fact plenty difficult. Most, if not all of your time will be probably be spent managing that godawful traffic. Learn the ways of the roundabout and the one-way street, and those problems can be conquered. Intersections are evil.Pros:+Large play area+Realistic graphics+Realistic simulations+Runs relatively well on older systems (see below)+Allows nearly-infinte city customization+Hydro dams!+Tons of mods to fix many game problems+Allows you to create your own vehicle/building assetsCons:-Dumb traffic AI-Pollution is too friendly-Street planning can be a nightmare due to lack of advanced tools-Eats RAM like there's no tomorrowIf you're a micromanaging SOB who hates drag-and-drop automatic games and wants to create graceful curving traffic systems, this is for you. If you still cling to your SimCity 2000 CD like it's a matter of life and death, you better get this game. If you're still playing SimCity BuildIt on your 2010 tablet, you probably aren't ready for this.

title: Recommended
comment: Rewriting this review because I can. And my old one wan't good. I've also played many more hours since then.So, in Cities:Skylines, you build cities. You control the taxes, roads, services, policies for districts, more roads and traffic, and that should be enough to entice you.After the disaster of SimCity 5 (2013), pretty much any other city builder is better. Now, this game took everything that got right (which wasn't that much . . .), got everything that SimCity 4 got right, made mods the best thing in the world, and a fantastic game was made.Never has any game just been so . . . good. I can't explain it. There are a few downsides, though.SimCity 5 had this one nice mechanic of "upgrading". That was cool. That's less important, since this game is the perfect mix between fun and simulator (SimCity 5 tried for fun, but it needed to go simulator, so there's another reason it's bad). Instead of a wind turbine farm, just place down each with so "hub station", or whatever they are.So it's worst thing isn't even that bad.Mods: They're fantastic. 'Nuff said.And on a side note, this is my favorite game on Steam. It beat Prison Architect, my now second favorite. This game is REALLY AMAZING.

title: Recommended
comment: Guide your plebs into existense and then murder them with their own excrement. 10/10City Simulator which does not include aliens, volcanos, tornadoes, or water-nados. 5/10The danger is lower, so the challenge is small, but it also isn't tedious. 6/10The grid is big to keep you alive, expand north, east, south, or west. 10/10It's got districts to help segregate the populations you don't like. Truckers don't go here, rich pants go here, and you people without educations don't go here, here, or here, but you can go here. If you like technology then you're welcome here. Could use more segregation tools to help futher keep the plebs down but I'm sure mods will work on that. 8/10The utilities are too easy to manage for my likeing it's almost like they just want you to make your city bigger, but I approve, the faster they rise, the faster you can kill them all and get that cemetery achievable. 6/10The viewables are pretty, and stable, they don't spasm and run across the screen. 8/10The modding is open and the community is sophisticated, awesome mods incoming. 10/10Over all, you do the math, but I think you're better off wasting time on this game them figure out the score.

title: Recommended
comment: I hear this is a great game for discerning fans of city sims. That may be, but all I can say is that it's also a great game for casual players, too. I don't play games like this for the challenge; I play for the city porn. That means I get great satisfaction out of attractive city blocks, creative neighborhoods, and tidy traffic flows. In Cities: Skylines I can indulge in that from the beginning, effortlessly enabling the mods I want for the experience I want. I also have to say this game is remarkably stable: I hasn't crashed on me once, and that's with the addition of dozens of workshop mods, some of which I installed in the middle of a savegame.

title: Recommended
comment: If you enjoy city builing on a truly massive scale, then this is defininately the game for you! Don't be fooled buy the two year old game play reviews on this game, it truly is worth your money.The only negative aspect about the franchise in my opinion is the cost of the DLC... That said, It still is a great game and i would recommend it to anyone who is in dire straits for a fresh perspective on large scale city building with great reward and a sense of accomplishment waiting around every turn.What really got me excited about this game is just how much better it is than simcity, but how much better it looks and feels. You are not limited to a small little space for building a city so small that eventually every corner you tried to keep seperate touches.In Cities:Skylines, you can really unleash your inner city builder and build a metropolis rivaled only but what is in your mind.The graphics in this game are also an absoulte wonder. If you wonder why, wait for nightfall and level out the camera to look over your city. Look at the water flowing in the rivers near your city, or even better, build a hydroelectric dam in your region and just watch the water build up on one end and drop down on the other. Watch your city closely during a rainy day or watch a forrest fire engulf half the wooded map in your region. What more is there???This game truly sets itself apart from any other city builder out there in more ways than I care to elaborate on.Go ahead and buy it, you won't be dissapointed!

comment: This is probably the best city simulator I have ever played.I was weary of getting this since the last city simulator to come out, Sim City, was a total disaster. But I saw this and everyone saying how good it was so I gave it a shot. It was the best $30 I have ever spent. Well worth it.Some of the features I love are how you can rename not only the buildings, but the people themselves. If you have a problem with saving money, you can either fix that in the economy panel or you can turn off a building. The people rarely complain about taxes up until about 15%, which is lovely as well.Some problems with the game that I have are the traffic (which can be fixed with mods I assume) and theres no weather system yet, which I hope Colossal Order and Paradox can bring in the future. Otherwise, do buy this game. You will not be disappointed.

comment: As my playtime suggests, I do enjoy this game as I have spent countless hours on it - At first I was interested in effeciently handling the sims but now I spend half if not most of the time modifing aesthetics instead of functionality. The workshop adds a ton more functionality and content and is the main reason I still play this game.A few essentials mods would be 81 tiles, extra landscaping tools, network extentions, surface painter & props and search box. Most importantly of all, the mod "Move it!" allows you to use keyboard controls to move already existing roads and buildings inch by inch. If you are going to downlaod alot of custom assets - Id highly recommend getting "Loading screen mod" to see the progress on loading since with a heavy mod loadout, it can feel like the loading screen isnt doing nothing stock.

title: Recommended
comment: Cities: Skylines, the best thing ever.TLDR: Well worth the money. Try it out, see if you enjoy it.I have written a few long reviews prior for different games, I'll try and keep this short. However, this game is just too fun. I usually play shooters, and RTS games, and I really thought when I purchased it that it would be poop. NOPE. I WAS WAY TO WRONG. It provides gameplay that is so simple, yet so good. The mods provide sexy additions which helps a lot. Steam workshop IS apart of C:Skylines. Very convient!Anyways, to the main review.Graphics: The game is VERY beautiful. I have a powerful-ish rig, and it runs too good on it. One of my friends has a pc from 2009 (very outdated, a ati hd 3450 and intel pentium). and he gets 50fps on it low. The game is optimized and the developers did a darn good job doing so. 9.5/10Sound: It sounds like a real city. I'd say it sounds very good and detailed. 8.5/10 A big higher quality would be better, but I am not focusing on the sound, as most people that play this aren't playing it for the sound.Gameplay: Well, heres the real deal. It's VERY good. Alright, I think I'm going to hire Donald Trump to say it: "It's YUUUUGGEEEE and very great folks!" Yes, it's very great. Honestly, you WILL spend hours on this. You could say: "Eh, I'm going to play for an hour"... *2 hours later* "Well, another 30 minutes"... *2 hours later*... "Oh, ****, my bad for missing work!". (Just kidding, but it's very addicting to those seeking a good city builder, and sandbox game. The gameplay is smooth and pretty simple. You will NOT break your back trying to learn the ropes. It might take some practice to not have as much traffic jams, and doing roads correctly... but that is where your creativity comes in. Either way, to make it short... 9.7/10. (I would like to see smarter AI in the base game)Re-Playable: I consider re-playable to be: You can play it times and times again, with no issue getting back into it. It will last you HOURS... and probably months. Especially with Steam WS! 10/10Overall: 9.5/10, just a devine and sexy game. I like flooding my citizens if they have a bad attitude. (Oh, they like getting wet).TLDR; Worth the money. Play it, I am 99.99% sure you will love it.MY ONE TIP: MAKE SURE YOU PLAN YOUR ZONES OUT. Industrial zones should have a direct connection to the highway. As well as commercial zones. Make sure you get a mass transit system up too. It helps. AND you WILL likely have traffic jams. DO NOT FLIP OUT. You can solve it by adding more exits/enterances and spacing out the zones.

title: Recommended
comment: This game is pretty good. It simulates building beautiful cities well and the player has a decent level of freedom in what they build. Mods enable a higher level. Speaking of mods there are quite a few great ones that should be in the base game. Like the ability to turn sirens off, without this mod everytime you move the camera to street level you will be deafened by ambo, fire and police sirens.Whats lacking from this game is dept in its management element, what's present is Ultra basic and really boring. I would have liked to see a large expansion to this element, I fear however that if they did get around to explaining city management it would likely be costly DLC.A lot of the dlc for this game isn't worth it so consider if it adds elements your like vs how much it costs.

title: Recommended
comment: This is the definitive city builder. Anything you could possibly want is in the worksop or is available as DLC (which is by no means necessary to enjoy the game).If you've ever enjoyed a city builder in your life this is a must buy. Even more so if it goes on sale for 75% off!My only critique would be the lack of modular buildings. When a real city outgrows the capabilities of its healthcare system it is rare that the city can afford to build a new hospital. They're most likely going to add a new wing to the one they already have! I would love to see that implemented into Cities Skylines for services like police, healthcare, fire, etc.

comment: There are some games that are completely addicting and force me to play for just another five minutes (which turns into hours). Cities: Skylines is one of those games. This game does what many city builders cannot. It has the feel of the Sim City series with just a few problems:-Traffic (4 and 6 lane roads are not helpful in most cases)-Not enough people per skyscraper building if you want realism. It's incredibly difficult (potentially impossible) to reach millions of people in your city-Not multiplayer and unable to attach your own cities together to create a bigger metropolis with more traffic issues (that was something that Sim City 4 still does well for singleplayer)Still the majority of the game is amazing fun with challenges to unlock important items for moving forward. I have no idea how many cities I have gone through and it still doesn't get old. It's a must have for anyone who enjoys a simulator.
